<item>
            <title>[LANG-1148] StringUtils.isBlank does not work correctly with strings containing non-breakable whitespace characters</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1148</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;isBlank uses java.lang.Character.isWhitespace(char ch) method, which has not been changed for a long time for backward compatibility. Over the years non-breakable whitespaces were introduced and are now used in some cases. So if we execute the code&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtils.isBlank(&quot;\u00A0&quot;); //returns false
org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtils.isBlank(&quot;\u202F&quot;); //returns false
org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtils.isBlank(&quot;\u2007&quot;); //returns false&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;we will get 3 falses, which is not right, according to StringUtils.isBlank documentation: &lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;Checks if a String is whitespace, empty (&quot;&quot;) or null.&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I suggest fixing it by using regex pattern &lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;&quot;^[\\p{Z}]*$&quot;&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt; instead of looping over the string characters. I know that it is a bit less fast than it works now, but it will work much more correctly. I would be glad to do it myself and write unit tests for it, so if you want, please contact me via email alex.bohush@gmail.com&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Additionally, I would modify the documentation itself too, because it does not tell that it returns true when meeting multiple whitespaces.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Windows 8.1 x64 , Java 1.8, but can be reproduced in any environment with an official Oracle JDK or JRE&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12837413">LANG-1148</key>
            <summary>StringUtils.isBlank does not work correctly with strings containing non-breakable whitespace characters</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="alexbogush">Aleksandr Bogush</reporter>

                            <label>test</label>
                    </labels>

                <updated>Mon, 12 Dec 2016 17:07:42 +0000</updated>

                                        <comments>
                            <comment id="14583562" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 12 Jun 2015 15:22:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;There is also the question of backward compatibility of StringUtils.isBlank.&lt;br/&gt;
Also there are other methods which use Character.isWhiteSpace, for example isNumericSpace.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m not convinced that the behaviour should be changed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14584486" author="alexbogush" created="Sat, 13 Jun 2015 07:07:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;~sebb@apache.org&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;, first of all thank you for the reply.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I agree with the backward compatibility point.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, I stumbled upon this issue using this method in my work project when parsing emails. The thing was that some email clients inserted non-break whitespaces instead of usual ones in their letters. It cost me a few angry letters from users, so I suggest at least mentioning this issue in the documentation (&lt;a href=&quot;http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/Character.html#isWhitespace(char)&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;like JDK developers did&lt;/a&gt;), because I had to dig into the source code and investigate what was wrong, so the proper docs would save me some time.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Anyway, now when you know about the issue, you can decide if the library needs new methods which consider non-break whitespaces.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14584601" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 13 Jun 2015 13:25:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Note that isWhiteSpace has been documented as excluding non-breaking spaces since at least Java 1.5 &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;, probably earlier.&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://docs.oracle.com/javase/1.5.0/docs/api/java/lang/Character.html#isWhitespace%28char%29&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://docs.oracle.com/javase/1.5.0/docs/api/java/lang/Character.html#isWhitespace%28char%29&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15295074" author="pascalschumacher" created="Sat, 21 May 2016 15:15:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I agree that non-breakable whitespace should be treated as whitespace. For example guava &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/google/guava/blob/8fbeb9038cbe8b382b1ee188ae8459203cd04fb5/guava/src/com/google/common/base/CharMatcher.java#L1217&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/google/guava/blob/8fbeb9038cbe8b382b1ee188ae8459203cd04fb5/guava/src/com/google/common/base/CharMatcher.java#L1217&lt;/a&gt; classifies non-breaking space as whitespace.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Of course there is the compatibility issue, so I guess a change like this should only be done in commons-lang 4.0.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15634351" author="pascalschumacher" created="Thu, 3 Nov 2016 21:27:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think we should consider changing this for 4.0.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15742198" author="dmjones500" created="Mon, 12 Dec 2016 14:51:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;FYI - &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=pascalschumacher&quot; class=&quot;user-hover&quot; rel=&quot;pascalschumacher&quot;&gt;Pascal Schumacher&lt;/a&gt; has updated the Javadoc for this method to make it clear which test is used:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Checks if a CharSequence is empty (&quot;&quot;), null or whitespace only.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Whitespace is defined by &lt;tt&gt;Character.isWhitespace(char)&lt;/tt&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Since the test is now clearly defined and there isn&apos;t much appetite for breaking backwards compatibility, I vote we don&apos;t attempt to fix this.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15742475" author="garydgregory" created="Mon, 12 Dec 2016 17:07:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I agree that this method should not break. We can add a NEW method though. A isAnyWhitespace()? Good Javadocs are key.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1147] EnumUtils *BitVector issue with more than 32 values Enum</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1147</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In &lt;b&gt;EnumUtils&lt;/b&gt; all &lt;em&gt;BitVector&lt;/em&gt; related methods fail in handling Enums with more than 32 values.&lt;br/&gt;
This is due to a implicit &lt;em&gt;int&lt;/em&gt; -&amp;gt; &lt;em&gt;long&lt;/em&gt; conversion in generating the Enum value &lt;em&gt;long&lt;/em&gt; mask.&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;&lt;b&gt;Bad code :&lt;/b&gt; here &lt;b&gt;1&lt;/b&gt; is an &lt;em&gt;int&lt;/em&gt; value so the &lt;b&gt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt;&lt;/b&gt; operation is done into an &lt;em&gt;int&lt;/em&gt; context and then, the result is converted to a &lt;em&gt;long&lt;/em&gt; value&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;long&lt;/span&gt; mask = 1 &amp;lt;&amp;lt; 32;    &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// -&amp;gt; mask = 1 and not 4294967296 (0x100000000)&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;b&gt;Good code :&lt;/b&gt; here &lt;b&gt;1L&lt;/b&gt; is a &lt;em&gt;long&lt;/em&gt; value so the &lt;b&gt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt;&lt;/b&gt; operation is done into an &lt;em&gt;long&lt;/em&gt; context&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;long&lt;/span&gt; mask = 1L &amp;lt;&amp;lt; 32;    &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// -&amp;gt; mask = 4294967296 (0x100000000)&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;See PR#97 : &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/97&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/97&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12837344">LANG-1147</key>
            <summary>EnumUtils *BitVector issue with more than 32 values Enum</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="2" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/critical.svg">Critical</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="rikles">Loic Guibert</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 12 Jun 2015 08:16:54 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 19 Oct 2016 07:01:08 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 12 Jun 2015 23:40:06 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14583141" author="githubbot" created="Fri, 12 Jun 2015 08:25:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;GitHub user rikles opened a pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/97&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/97&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1147&quot; title=&quot;EnumUtils *BitVector issue with more than 32 values Enum&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1147&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1147&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; : Fix EnumUtils *BitVector issue with more than 32 values Enums&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    In `EnumUtils` all &lt;em&gt;BitVector&lt;/em&gt; related methods fail in handling Enum with more than 32 values.&lt;br/&gt;
    This is due to a implicit `int` -&amp;gt; `long` conversion in generating the Enum value `long` mask.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    ```java&lt;br/&gt;
    // Bad code : here `1` is an `int` value so the `&amp;lt;&amp;lt;` operation is done into an `int` context and then, the result is converted to a `long` value&lt;br/&gt;
    long mask = 1 &amp;lt;&amp;lt; 32;    // -&amp;gt; mask = 1 and not 4294967296 (0x100000000)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    // Good code : here `1L` is a `long` value so the `&amp;lt;&amp;lt;` operation is done into an `long` context&lt;br/&gt;
    long mask = 1L &amp;lt;&amp;lt; 32;    // -&amp;gt; mask = 4294967296 (0x100000000)&lt;br/&gt;
    ```&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    I fixed this and add some tests into `EnumUtilsTest` with a 64 values Enum.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    $ git pull &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/rikles/commons-lang&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/rikles/commons-lang&lt;/a&gt; fix-&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1147&quot; title=&quot;EnumUtils *BitVector issue with more than 32 values Enum&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1147&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1147&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/97.patch&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/97.patch&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch&lt;br/&gt;
with (at least) the following in the commit message:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    This closes #97&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;
&lt;p&gt;commit 1c9e5139f2b515f8741fbcb9c9b0f398d22d73ca&lt;br/&gt;
Author: Loic Guibert &amp;lt;lfdummy-apache@yahoo.fr&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1147&quot; title=&quot;EnumUtils *BitVector issue with more than 32 values Enum&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1147&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1147&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; : Fix EnumUtils *BitVector issue with more than 32 values Enums&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1144] Multiple calls of org.apache.commons.lang3.concurrent.LazyInitializer.initialize() are possible</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1144</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;It is possible to create a construct, that allows multiple calls of LazyInitializer.initialize, when calculations (which can be very expensive) return null as result. &lt;br/&gt;
In the Javadoc is described that the initialize method will be called only on the first access&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    /**
     * Creates and initializes the object managed by &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;this&lt;/span&gt; {@code
     * LazyInitializer}. This method is called by {@link #get()} when the object
     * is accessed &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; the first time. An implementation can focus on the
     * creation of the object. No synchronization is needed, as &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;this&lt;/span&gt; is already
     * handled by {@code get()}.
     *
     * @&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; the managed data object
     * @&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; ConcurrentException &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; an error occurs during object creation
     */
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;protected&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;abstract&lt;/span&gt; T initialize() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; ConcurrentException;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The Junit Test can be something like this:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;b&gt;(fix can be appplied from attached patch-file)&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;package&lt;/span&gt; edu.test;

&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;

&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; org.apache.commons.lang3.concurrent.ConcurrentException;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; org.apache.commons.lang3.concurrent.LazyInitializer;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; org.junit.Test;

&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;LazyInitializerTest {

  &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;private&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; lazyinitCounter = 0;

  &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;private&lt;/span&gt; LazyInitializer&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Object&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt; lazyIinit = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; LazyInitializer&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Object&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt;() {

    @Override
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;protected&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Object&lt;/span&gt; initialize() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; ConcurrentException {
      lazyinitCounter++;
      &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; doSomeVeryExpensiveOperations();
    }
  };
  
  
  &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;private&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Object&lt;/span&gt; doSomeVeryExpensiveOperations() {
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;do&lt;/span&gt; db calls
&lt;/span&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;do&lt;/span&gt; some complex math calculations
&lt;/span&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// the result of them all is &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/span&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;;
  }
  
  
  @Test
  &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void testInitialization() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; Exception {
    lazyIinit.get();
    lazyIinit.get();
    assertEquals(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;Multiple call of LazyInitializer#initialize&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, 1, lazyinitCounter);
  }

}


&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Java 1.8 on Windows 7 x64&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12836937">LANG-1144</key>
            <summary>Multiple calls of org.apache.commons.lang3.concurrent.LazyInitializer.initialize() are possible</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="ggregory">Gary D. Gregory</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="waldemar">Waldemar Maier</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 10 Jun 2015 20:07:28 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Jun 2017 12:04:47 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 23 Oct 2016 17:37:32 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.4</version>
                    <version>3.5</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.6</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.concurrent.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>3</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14582444" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Thu, 11 Jun 2015 20:03:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I do not think that this is really a critical problem. The use case that a longer and complex calculation yields a null result at the end seems a bit odd to me.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;And - as you have a demonstrated in your patch - there is an easy work-around for the problem: Just use a special null object or a wrapper type like MutableObject or the new Java 8 type Optional. I would be reluctant to add such means to the current implementation because this increases complexity and is (slightly) less efficient. This is IMHO a too high price for such a corner use case.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;What should be done in any case is to add a note to the Javadocs describing this problem.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15598131" author="garydgregory" created="Sat, 22 Oct 2016 16:47:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This seems like a valid bug report to me.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I do not think it reasonable to ask user to create a &quot;special&quot; null value for a JDBC Connection or Statement, for example:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;LazyInitializer&amp;lt;java.sql.Connection&amp;gt;
LazyInitializer&amp;lt;java.sql.Statement&amp;gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Now, I have to go and implement a &quot;null&quot; implementation of all the interfaces I want to use? That&apos;s not acceptable.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Furthermore, what if I have a &lt;tt&gt;ComplexSomething&lt;/tt&gt; class with many private final fields that get initialized on construction to create a valid object? I now have to change the class to allow for all null values? Not acceptable either.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15598136" author="garydgregory" created="Sat, 22 Oct 2016 16:51:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I wish I had paid more attention when this class was added because &lt;tt&gt;org.apache.commons.lang3.concurrent.LazyInitializer.get()&lt;/tt&gt; throwing a custom &lt;tt&gt;ConcurrentException&lt;/tt&gt; does not make sense to me either. That&apos;s because if I catch an error while I am building my object, it might have nothing to do with concurrency. The fact that the LI class helps me deal with concurrency matters, yes. This should be an &lt;tt&gt;IllegalStateException&lt;/tt&gt;. We could change this for 4.0 I suppose.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15598178" author="garydgregory" created="Sat, 22 Oct 2016 17:19:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Proposed patch. You could do away with the Null class and just use a &quot;new Object()&quot; as the null value.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15598405" author="garydgregory" created="Sat, 22 Oct 2016 20:04:07 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch that follows the same double lock idiom.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15599914" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Sun, 23 Oct 2016 16:13:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The patch looks good to me, but I would propose to make the special noInit object even &lt;b&gt;static&lt;/b&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Regarding exception handling: I think, the currently implemented solution is in-line with the approach taken by the JDK. See for instance &lt;tt&gt;Future.get()&lt;/tt&gt;, which throws an &lt;tt&gt;ExecutionException&lt;/tt&gt;. There is also some support for the exception type in the &lt;tt&gt;ConcurrentUtils&lt;/tt&gt; class.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15600026" author="garydgregory" created="Sun, 23 Oct 2016 17:37:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In Git master. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please verify and close.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1142] StringUtils#capitalize: Javadoc says toTitleCase; code uses toUpperCase</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1142</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The capitalize Javadoc says the code uses  Character#toTitleCase, however the code actually uses Character#toUpperCase.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Generally these produce the same result, but some charsets may have different characters for upper and title case - see for example the Javadoc &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; for Character#isTitleCase.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The way I read this, the character that looks like &quot;lj&quot; is lower-case, &quot;LJ&quot; is upper case and &quot;Lj&quot; is title case - i.e. not the same.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The question here is: should the code be corrected to use TitleCase or should the Javadoc be corrected to use UpperCase?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/Character.html#isTitleCase%28char%29&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/Character.html#isTitleCase%28char%29&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12835778">LANG-1142</key>
            <summary>StringUtils#capitalize: Javadoc says toTitleCase; code uses toUpperCase</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebb">Sebb</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 5 Jun 2015 17:24:33 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sun, 19 Jul 2015 08:28:24 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 19 Jul 2015 08:27:07 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14632726" author="bayard" created="Sun, 19 Jul 2015 08:21:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It definitely should use toTitleCase. I wonder when that changed. &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/sad.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Looks like it was changed in &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/StringUtils.java?r1=1673944&amp;amp;r2=1673943&amp;amp;pathrev=1673944&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/StringUtils.java?r1=1673944&amp;amp;r2=1673943&amp;amp;pathrev=1673944&lt;/a&gt; - &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1058&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1058&lt;/a&gt; - which fortunately is unreleased.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14632730" author="bayard" created="Sun, 19 Jul 2015 08:27:07 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;$ git commit&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;master 421db38&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Switched capitalize back to using toTitleCase. Added a test for this using the &apos;Lj&apos; letter. &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1142&quot; title=&quot;StringUtils#capitalize: Javadoc says toTitleCase; code uses toUpperCase&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1142&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1142&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
 2 files changed, 4 insertions&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/add.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;, 1 deletion&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/forbidden.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1141] StrLookup.systemPropertiesLookup() no longer reacts on changes on system properties</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1141</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In versions of Commons Lang before 3.4 a &lt;tt&gt;Lookup&lt;/tt&gt; object created from the &lt;tt&gt;systemPropertiesLookup()&lt;/tt&gt; method offered a live view of system properties. So if a system property was changed after the creation of the lookup object, the new value was visible. In version 3.4 this is no longer the case.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The change seems to be related to &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1055&quot; title=&quot;StrSubstitutor.replaceSystemProperties does not work consistently&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1055&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1055&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;. Here a fix was implemented which initializes a lookup object for system properties with a snapshot copy of the current properties. Changes made later on system properties are no longer reflected. I do not understand the background for this change because this is not really related to the original bug report.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I would propose an implementation which fixes the reported problem in &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1055&quot; title=&quot;StrSubstitutor.replaceSystemProperties does not work consistently&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1055&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1055&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; and allows a live view on system properties. Maybe the snapshot use case could still be supported by an overloaded method.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12834790">LANG-1141</key>
            <summary>StrLookup.systemPropertiesLookup() no longer reacts on changes on system properties</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="oheger">Oliver Heger</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 2 Jun 2015 20:13:07 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 19 Oct 2016 07:00:56 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 24 Jun 2015 20:26:56 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.4</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.text.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14573440" author="oliver.heger@t-online.de" created="Thu, 4 Jun 2015 19:34:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Proposed patch to solve both &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1055&quot; title=&quot;StrSubstitutor.replaceSystemProperties does not work consistently&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1055&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1055&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1141&quot; title=&quot;StrLookup.systemPropertiesLookup() no longer reacts on changes on system properties&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1141&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1141&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;. This patch implements the lookup for system properties in a very straight-forward way. It ensures live access to system properties in all cases in a consistent way.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14596313" author="britter" created="Mon, 22 Jun 2015 17:45:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hello Oliver,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;patch looks good to me. I&apos;m not sure but I think that os.name is set to HAL-9000 on the ASF build servers. So maybe it would be better to set the &lt;tt&gt;differentOsName&lt;/tt&gt; like this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; differentOsName = originalOsName + &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;-TEST&quot;&lt;/span&gt;;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.setProperty(osName, differentOsName);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1140] lang.reflect.FieldUtils.getAllFields() returns false result</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1140</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;JUnit test returns errors below.&lt;br/&gt;
   FieldUtilsTest.testGetAllFields:154 expected:&amp;lt;5&amp;gt; but was:&amp;lt;7&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
   FieldUtilsTest.testGetAllFieldsList:168 expected:&amp;lt;5&amp;gt; but was:&amp;lt;7&amp;gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Both methods has a parameter &quot;FieldUtils.getAllFields(PublicChild.class).length .&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
PublicChild which has 1 field extends Parent which has 4 fields.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I made a dummy class which contains no field, the result of getAllFields() was 1, not 0.&lt;br/&gt;
Lang-3.4 doesn&apos;t have this problem.&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-style: solid;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeHeader panelHeader&quot; style=&quot;border-bottom-width: 1px;border-bottom-style: solid;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;PublicChild2.java&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;PublicChild2 {

	&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; VALUE = &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;child&quot;&lt;/span&gt;;
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-style: solid;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeHeader panelHeader&quot; style=&quot;border-bottom-width: 1px;border-bottom-style: solid;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;FieldUtilsTest.java&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;assertEquals(1, PublicChild2.&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class.&lt;/span&gt;getDeclaredFields().length);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Result: fails. returns 2&lt;/p&gt;</description>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1132] ReflectionToStringBuilder doesn&apos;t throw IllegalArgumentException when the constructor&apos;s object param is null</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1132</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Placeholder for &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/85&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/85&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;As described in it&apos;s &lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/javadocs/api-release/org/apache/commons/lang3/builder/ReflectionToStringBuilder.html#ReflectionToStringBuilder(java.lang.Object)&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;javadoc&lt;/a&gt;, ReflectionToStringBuilder constructor will throw IllegalArgumentException if the Object to build a toStringfor is null, while in fact it won&apos;t.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12827530">LANG-1132</key>
            <summary>ReflectionToStringBuilder doesn&apos;t throw IllegalArgumentException when the constructor&apos;s object param is null</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="britter">Benedikt Ritter</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="jacktan1991">Jack Tan</reporter>
                        <labels>
                            <label>github</label>
                            <label>github-pullrequest</label>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 6 May 2015 03:32:29 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 19 Oct 2016 07:01:10 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 7 May 2015 18:46:07 +0000</resolved>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1131] StrBuilder.equals(StrBuilder) doesn&apos;t check for null inputs</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1131</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The following test will fail because the &lt;tt&gt;equals(StrBuilder)&lt;/tt&gt; overload in &lt;tt&gt;StrBuilder&lt;/tt&gt; does not check for null inputs:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    @Test
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void testEqualsWithNullStrBuilder() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; Exception {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; StrBuilder sb = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; StrBuilder();
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; StrBuilder other = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;;
        assertFalse(sb.equals(other));
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12827351">LANG-1131</key>
            <summary>StrBuilder.equals(StrBuilder) doesn&apos;t check for null inputs</summary>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1128] JsonToStringStyle doesn&apos;t handle chars and objects correctly</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1128</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Placeholder for &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/74&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/74&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;except number, boolean, Array and nested object structures, other types like char, String, Date etc. in java should be appendAsString.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;add method &lt;tt&gt;appendDetail(StringBuffer buffer, String fieldName, char value) to JsonToStringStyle&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
modify &lt;tt&gt;appendDetail(StringBuffer buffer, String fieldName, Object value)&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1126] DateFormatUtilsTest.testSMTP depends on the default Locale</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1126</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;DateFormatUtilsTest.testSMTP depends on the default Locale and expects this to be Locale.EN. When running the test with the different default Locale (e.g. Locale.GERMANY) it will fail with the following message:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;org.junit.ComparisonFailure: 
Expected :Sun, 08 Jun 2003 10:11:12 -0300
Actual   :So, 08 Jun 2003 10:11:12 -0300
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Solution: Set the default Locale before the test runs and reset it afterwards.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12826526">LANG-1126</key>
            <summary>DateFormatUtilsTest.testSMTP depends on the default Locale</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>

In the mean time you can get the release notes for 3.4 from &lt;a href=&quot;https://dist.apache.org/repos/dist/release/commons/lang/RELEASE-NOTES.txt&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://dist.apache.org/repos/dist/release/commons/lang/RELEASE-NOTES.txt&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;$ svn ci -m &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;LANG-1125: No release notes &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; version 3.4&quot;&lt;/span&gt; lang-site/

Transmitting file data .

&lt;/pre&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1123] Unit test FastDatePrinterTimeZonesTest needs a timezone set</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1123</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In file :&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;src/test/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/time/FastDatePrinterTimeZonesTest.java
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The unit test testCalendarTimezoneRespected set a timezone for the expectedValue but none for the actualValue. Because the actualValue use always the default timezone, then It has to fail.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Actually, there is no fail because of a bug in FastDatePrinter.format() method (see &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-916&quot; title=&quot;CLONE - DateFormatUtils.format does not correctly change Calendar TimeZone in certain situations&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-916&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-916&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When applying the &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-916&quot; title=&quot;CLONE - DateFormatUtils.format does not correctly change Calendar TimeZone in certain situations&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-916&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-916&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; patch, the unit test flood more than 600 failed:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;cpm &amp;gt; mvn test
Failed tests:
[...]
  FastDatePrinterTimeZonesTest.testCalendarTimezoneRespected:61 expected:&amp;lt;[2:19PM EDT]&amp;gt; but was:&amp;lt;[6:19PM UTC]&amp;gt;
  FastDatePrinterTimeZonesTest.testCalendarTimezoneRespected:61 expected:&amp;lt;[2:19PM AST]&amp;gt; but was:&amp;lt;[6:19PM UTC]&amp;gt;
  FastDatePrinterTimeZonesTest.testCalendarTimezoneRespected:61 expected:&amp;lt;[12:19PM MDT]&amp;gt; but was:&amp;lt;[6:19PM UTC]&amp;gt;
  FastDatePrinterTimeZonesTest.testCalendarTimezoneRespected:61 expected:&amp;lt;[1:19PM ACT]&amp;gt; but was:&amp;lt;[6:19PM UTC]&amp;gt;
[...]
Tests run: 3544, Failures: 617, Errors: 0, Skipped: 5
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Java 6, timezone is &quot;Europe/Paris&quot; (GMT/UTC +01:00), GNU/Linux.&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12826190">LANG-1123</key>

                            <comment id="14522674" author="charles_honton@intuit.com" created="Fri, 1 May 2015 02:24:45 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;changelist 775203dd2cfce017910d04c58a0b1b4e0a64923c&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1122] Inconsistent behavior of swap for malformed inputs</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1122</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Following the discussion at &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/47&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/47&lt;/a&gt; we need to decide how malformed inputs should be handled by the swap method. We have to handle several forms of malformed inputs and we should decide how to do that based on the current behavior of ArrayUtils. Malformed inputs are:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ol&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;array == null&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;array.length == 0&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;offset1 &amp;lt; 0&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;offset2 &amp;lt; 0&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;len &amp;lt; 0&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;offset1 &amp;gt; offset2&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;offset1 &amp;gt; array.length&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;offset2 &amp;gt; array.length&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;offset1 + len &amp;gt; array.length&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;offset2 + len &amp;gt; array.length&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ol&gt;
</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12826024">LANG-1122</key>
            <summary>Inconsistent behavior of swap for malformed inputs</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="britter">Benedikt Ritter</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="britter">Benedikt Ritter</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 29 Apr 2015 17:37:45 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 19 Oct 2016 07:01:17 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 7 May 2015 18:33:08 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>3.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>3</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14519794" author="githubbot" created="Wed, 29 Apr 2015 17:38:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user britter commented on the pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/47#issuecomment-97514318&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/47#issuecomment-97514318&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Hello @beradrian,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    sorry for being so oblivious. Yes it would be best to create a separate PR for this issue. I&apos;ve already created a new jira issue for tracking this: &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1122&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1122&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14521148" author="beradrian" created="Thu, 30 Apr 2015 08:46:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I guess start is the start of first block (in swap methods - offset1), end is the start of second block (in swap methods - offset2) and offset is the length of block to swap (in swap methods - len).&lt;br/&gt;
For case 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8 I propose to result in no op. For case 6, it actually doesn&apos;t matter which block is first.&lt;br/&gt;
For case 9 and 10 - what do you think it should happen with swap(&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1, 2, 3, 4, 5&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;, 0, 3, 3)? It should result in no op or it should result in &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;4, 5, 3, 1, 2&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;, meaning that it will swap as many as possible? I would incline to go for the latter.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14524135" author="britter" created="Fri, 1 May 2015 22:27:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hello &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=beradrian&quot; class=&quot;user-hover&quot; rel=&quot;beradrian&quot;&gt;Adrian Ber&lt;/a&gt;,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;yes I meant offset1, offset2 and len. I&apos;ve adjusted the description of this issue.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I agree with your assessment of 1, 2, and 6, 7, 8. For 3, 4, and 5 we should take into account how other methods with index parameters behave for negative inputs. For example the indexOf methods treat a negative startIndex as zero. However the remove methods throw an &lt;tt&gt;IndexOutOfBoundsException&lt;/tt&gt;. We should do either of this, but we shouldn&apos;t introduce yet another way of handling negative indicies.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For case 9 and 10, I&apos;m fine with the proposed solution.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14526414" author="beradrian" created="Mon, 4 May 2015 08:35:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;For case 5, even if we promote len to zero, it will have the same result - no op.&lt;br/&gt;
If we will use the principle &quot;swap as many as possible from the given offset onwards&quot; in all cases then 5 and 6 will promote the indices to zero. And then it will be consistent with 9 and 10 behavior too. And it will also be easy to document it too &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;.&lt;br/&gt;
What do you think?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14527174" author="britter" created="Mon, 4 May 2015 20:04:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Go for it!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14532247" author="githubbot" created="Thu, 7 May 2015 08:37:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;GitHub user beradrian opened a pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/86&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/86&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Fix issue 1122&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Fixes issue &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1122&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1122&lt;/a&gt; as discussed.&lt;br/&gt;
    I also added a link to an article on my blog about shift algorithm, as it was discussed previously. Hope it&apos;s fine, if not, I can remove it.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    $ git pull &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/beradrian/commons-lang&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/beradrian/commons-lang&lt;/a&gt; master&lt;/p&gt;

with (at least) the following in the commit message:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    This closes #86&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;
&lt;p&gt;commit 5b7608d1549989d92dd159392c19d9ba8ce0e62e&lt;br/&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    consistent treatment for negative indices for swap method&lt;/p&gt;

Author: beradrian &amp;lt;beradrian@yahoo.com&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;

                            <comment id="14533152" author="githubbot" created="Thu, 7 May 2015 18:32:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user asfgit closed the pull request at:&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1121] FastDateFormat.parse() does not handle wrong length string</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1121</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;FDFP does not handled wrong length string.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;for example,&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// Wed Apr 29 00:00:00 KST 2015
&lt;/span&gt;FastDateFormat.getInstance(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;yyyyMMdd&quot;&lt;/span&gt;).parse(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;20150429&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; ParseException
&lt;/span&gt;FastDateFormat.getInstance(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;yyyyMMdd&quot;&lt;/span&gt;).parse(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;2015&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// Thu Mar 16 00:00:00 KST 81724
&lt;/span&gt;FastDateFormat.getInstance(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;yyyyMMdd&quot;&lt;/span&gt;).parse(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;20150429113100&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;I think result of third throws ParseException,&lt;br/&gt;
but FastDateFormat.parse() returns wrong year, ex, 81724 instead of 2015.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As I tested,&lt;br/&gt;
regex.matcher.group =&amp;gt; (2015)(04)(29113100) =&amp;gt; setCalendar =&amp;gt; March 16, 81724&lt;/p&gt;
</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12825791">LANG-1121</key>
            <summary>FastDateFormat.parse() does not handle wrong length string</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="6">Invalid</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="chonton">Charles Honton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="freeism">Henry Kang</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 29 Apr 2015 04:57:21 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 19 Oct 2016 15:24:45 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 30 Apr 2015 16:18:11 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.3.2</version>

                        <due></due>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14518798" author="britter" created="Wed, 29 Apr 2015 06:09:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patches welcome! Don&apos;t forget to include a junit test &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14521748" author="charles_honton@intuit.com" created="Thu, 30 Apr 2015 16:18:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Commit cb83f7cb31e50f265e098c5380b3f0051e257f46 has a test to show that this is same behavior as SimpleDateFormat.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14532030" author="freeism" created="Thu, 7 May 2015 05:25:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for commit tests.&lt;br/&gt;
I agree that is same behavior as SimpleDateFormat.&lt;br/&gt;
However, It is incorrect operation, I think.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;format : yyyyMMdd&lt;br/&gt;
input : 20150429113100&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It matches pattern below&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;(\p{Nd{4}}+)(\p{Nd{2}+)(\p{Nd}++)&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;It works yyyy, MM, and the others are dd (don&apos;t care how long digits)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Is there any plan for patches, or not?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14533251" author="britter" created="Thu, 7 May 2015 19:34:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=freeism&quot; class=&quot;user-hover&quot; rel=&quot;freeism&quot;&gt;Henry Kang&lt;/a&gt;, no I don&apos;t think so, because FastDateFormat is supposed to be a replacement for SimpleDateFormat, so it has to behave the same way.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14533848" author="freeism" created="Fri, 8 May 2015 04:40:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Ok, Thank you for reply. <item>
            <title>[LANG-1120] StringUtils.stripAccents from &quot;&#321;&quot; and &quot;&#322;&quot;</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1120</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; org.apache.commons.lang3.StringUtils;

&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;Main {

    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; void main(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;[] args) {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(StringUtils.stripAccents(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;&#260;&#321;&#211;&#346;&#379;&#377;&#262;&#323; &#261;&#322;&#243;&#347;&#380;&#378;&#263;&#324;&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
    }
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;win&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12825473">LANG-1120</key>
            <summary>StringUtils.stripAccents from &quot;&#321;&quot; and &quot;&#322;&quot;</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    @Test
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void testLANG1120() &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; Exception {
        assertEquals(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;ALOSZZCN aloszzcn&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, StringUtils.stripAccents(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;&#260;&#321;&#211;&#346;&#379;&#377;&#262;&#323; &#261;&#322;&#243;&#347;&#380;&#378;&#263;&#324;&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;/pre&gt;

                        <customfieldvalues>
                            
                        </customfieldvalues>

    </item>


<item>
            <title>[LANG-1118] StringUtils.repeat(&apos;z&apos;, -1) throws NegativeArraySizeException</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1118</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Unlike what is said in JavaDoc comment, when passing a negative repeat value to the &lt;b&gt;StringUtils.repeat(char, int)&lt;/b&gt; function, it doesn&apos;t return an empty String but throws a &lt;em&gt;NegativeArraySizeException&lt;/em&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;See PR #72 : &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/72&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/72&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12823378">LANG-1118</key>
            <summary>StringUtils.repeat(&apos;z&apos;, -1) throws NegativeArraySizeException</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="britter">Benedikt Ritter</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="rikles">Loic Guibert</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 23 Apr 2015 11:30:47 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 19 Oct 2016 07:01:28 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 28 Apr 2015 19:38:04 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>3.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>3</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14508908" author="githubbot" created="Thu, 23 Apr 2015 11:50:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;GitHub user rikles opened a pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/68&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/68&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1118&quot; title=&quot;StringUtils.repeat(&amp;#39;z&amp;#39;, -1) throws NegativeArraySizeException&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1118&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1118&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; Fix StringUtils.repeat(char, int)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Now doing what is said in JavaDoc comment :&lt;br/&gt;
    when passing a negative repeat value to the StringUtils.repeat(char, int) function, it returns an empty String instead of throwing a NegativeArraySizeException.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    $ git pull &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/rikles/commons-lang&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/rikles/commons-lang&lt;/a&gt; fix-&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1118&quot; title=&quot;StringUtils.repeat(&amp;#39;z&amp;#39;, -1) throws NegativeArraySizeException&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1118&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1118&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/68.patch&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/68.patch&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch&lt;br/&gt;
with (at least) the following in the commit message:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    This closes #68&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1116] DateUtilsTest.testLang530 fails for some timezones</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1116</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Unit test for testLang530 fails when the isoDateStr comes out with just a Z instead of +00:00.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;Tests run: 38, Failures: 0, Errors: 1, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 0.014 sec &amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt; FAILURE! - in org.apache.commons.lang3.time.DateUtilsTest
testLang530(org.apache.commons.lang3.time.DateUtilsTest)  Time elapsed: 0.005 sec  &amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt; ERROR!
java.text.ParseException: Unable to parse the date: 2015-04-17T18:51:52Z
        at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.DateUtils.parseDateWithLeniency(DateUtils.java:401)
        at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.DateUtils.parseDate(DateUtils.java:301)
        at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.DateUtils.parseDate(DateUtils.java:278)
        at org.apache.commons.lang3.time.DateUtilsTest.testLang530(DateUtilsTest.java:1222)
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;On a Linux machine where this test passes, isoDateStr is 2015-04-17T19:26:03+00:00.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Redhat 5 / Java8u45&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12821994">LANG-1116</key>
            <summary>DateUtilsTest.testLang530 fails for some timezones</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="chonton">Charles Honton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="asheldon">Aaron Sheldon</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 17 Apr 2015 20:46:09 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 19 Oct 2016 07:00:46 +0000</updated>
