 .../java/org/apache/commons/lang3/StringUtils.java | 15 ++++++++++++---&lt;br/&gt;
 .../lang3/StringUtilsEqualsIndexOfTest.java        | 17 +++++++++++++++--&lt;br/&gt;
 3 files changed, 28 insertions&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/add.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;, 6 deletions&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/forbidden.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
----------------------------------------------------------------------&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="15053018" author="lihy70" created="Fri, 11 Dec 2015 16:58:58 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Sebb, &lt;br/&gt;
The original bug is: StringUtils.ordinalIndexOf(&quot;aaaaaa&quot;, &quot;aa&quot;, 2) should return 2. somehow title was changed:  &lt;br/&gt;
&quot;StringUtils.ordinalIndexOf(&quot;aaaaaa&quot;, &quot;aa&quot;, 2) != 2 in StringUtils&quot; to &quot;StringUtils.ordinalIndexOf(&quot;aaaaaa&quot;, &quot;aa&quot;, 2) != 3&lt;br/&gt;
And wrong patch was merged into trunk.&lt;br/&gt;
The right code should be:&lt;br/&gt;
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------&lt;br/&gt;
    private static int ordinalIndexOf(final CharSequence str, final CharSequence searchStr, final int ordinal, final boolean lastIndex) {&lt;br/&gt;
        if (str == null || searchStr == null || ordinal &amp;lt;= 0) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            return INDEX_NOT_FOUND;
        }

&lt;p&gt;        if (searchStr.length() == 0) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            return lastIndex ? str.length() : 0;
        }

&lt;p&gt;        final int searchStrLen = searchStr.length();&lt;br/&gt;
        int index = lastIndex ? str.length() : 0;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        for (int found = 0; index &amp;gt;= 0&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; {&lt;br/&gt;
            if (lastIndex) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                index = CharSequenceUtils.lastIndexOf(str, searchStr, index);
            }
&lt;p&gt; else &lt;/p&gt;
{
                index = CharSequenceUtils.indexOf(str, searchStr, index);
            }

&lt;p&gt;            if (index &amp;lt; 0) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                return INDEX_NOT_FOUND;
            }

&lt;p&gt;            if (++found &amp;gt;= ordinal) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                break;
            }

&lt;p&gt;            index = lastIndex ? index - searchStrLen : index + searchStrLen;&lt;br/&gt;
        }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        return index;&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;br/&gt;
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;please look into the original code.&lt;br/&gt;
This is a valid bug. It&apos;s can&apos;t be correct by just updating java doc. because it may confuse people.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;BTW, the bug was reported on 12/11/2014,  today is 12/11/15&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15053099" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 11 Dec 2015 17:50:18 +0000"  >&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;The original bug is: StringUtils.ordinalIndexOf(&quot;aaaaaa&quot;, &quot;aa&quot;, 2) should return 2.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Sorry, but that is wrong.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The code returns &lt;b&gt;all&lt;/b&gt; matches, so the first match is &quot;aa....&quot;, i.e. index 0.&lt;br/&gt;
The second match is &quot;.aa...&quot;, i.e. index 1.&lt;br/&gt;
Third match would be &quot;..aa..&quot;, i.e. index 2.&lt;br/&gt;
etc.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15053124" author="lihy70" created="Fri, 11 Dec 2015 18:07:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Sebb, &lt;br/&gt;
It doesn&apos;t make sense. take a few minutes to think about the definition/contract of &quot;indexOf&quot;, and consider &quot;searchStr&quot; as whole object, no matter it&apos;s &quot;aa&quot;, or &quot;ab&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Or, try to think about the question:&lt;br/&gt;
There is one string A: &quot;aaaaaa&quot;, string B: &quot;aa&quot;, how many B in A and return the index of each?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15053159" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 11 Dec 2015 18:31:54 +0000"  >&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;There is one string A: &quot;aaaaaa&quot;, string B: &quot;aa&quot;, how many B in A and return the index of each?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There are 5 B in A, indexes 0,1,2,3,4&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Remember that overlapping matches are allowed, and indexes start at 0.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15053183" author="lihy70" created="Fri, 11 Dec 2015 18:44:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;There are ONLY 3 B in A. &lt;br/&gt;
Consider the case: A: &quot;ababab&quot;, B: &quot;ab&quot;, or A:&quot;aaaaaa&quot;, B: &quot;aa&quot;. in different scenarios, the expected result should be same, not matter what in A and B. &lt;br/&gt;
You are assuming the programmers always know what in B or have to check what in B, and remember what they should NOT when call this method.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15053390" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 11 Dec 2015 19:15:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The difference with &quot;ab&quot; is that it cannot ever match overlapping sections of the string.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However consider A: &quot;ababab&quot; B: &quot;aba&quot;. B matches at index 0, it also matches at index 2.&lt;br/&gt;
Similarly for B: &quot;abab&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As I already wrote, the method allows overlapping matches.&lt;br/&gt;
It did so until version 3.4 when the code was changed, breaking it in the process (e.g. JIRA-1193)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I agree that the Javadoc was not precise, as it did not specify whether or not overlapping matches should be allowed.&lt;br/&gt;
The Javadoc has now been clarified to agree with the original behaviour.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It would of course be possible to have a different strategy whereby overlapping matches were not allowed, but that would be a change from the original behaviour, so would need a new method in order to avoid breaking the code for users that rely on the original behaviour.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15053411" author="lihy70" created="Fri, 11 Dec 2015 19:27:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It&apos;s 19:18 at London?  how are you doing today? It&apos;s Friday. Here is 11:18 at CA.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;JIRA-1193 is broken by wrong patch. the right code will work fine and fix JIRA-1193.&lt;br/&gt;
You&apos;re keeping talking &quot;overlapping matches&quot;. This is a general XXXIndexOf(...), not a match method...&lt;br/&gt;
The doc looks good to me. what wrong is the behavior/code in the method. Even the java doc is updated with &quot;overlapping matches  is allowed&quot;. People may NOT notice it, or remember it, or even don&apos;t read the doc. It could bring bugs by unexpected result even doc is updated.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15053437" author="tn" created="Fri, 11 Dec 2015 19:45:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This code exists since a long time and looking at the implementation it is clear what it does and what its intention is: repeatedly execute indexOf with a start index of +1 compared to the last match. There are even suggestions on stackoverflow to use this method for exactly that use-case.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;What you are facing is a corner-case that was not described in the javadoc and thus it might create confusion for a user. So the right thing to do is what sebb did: revert the fix to the previous, working version and update the javadoc to document the corner case. Contrary to your opinion that this might introduce bugs, it is quite the opposite, your fix will introduce bugs as people relied on the previous version for a long time already.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If there is a need for a method that does not handle overlaps, then this should be a new feature request. The method could have an additional flag to indicate how it handles overlaps.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15053470" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 11 Dec 2015 19:57:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I agree that had the patch been &apos;better&apos; it would not have caused JIRA-1193 to be raised. In fact I was originally going to try to fix it accordingly.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, I looked further into it, and noticed that fixing the behaviour according to your original issue was not a good idea, as it would have changed the existing behaviour.&lt;br/&gt;
The code was added to LANG in version 2.1 about 12 years ago, and the behaviour did not change until 3.4 which broke it.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Although the behaviour is not what you expect, it is consistent with the original Javadoc.&lt;br/&gt;
Furthermore the behaviour has been the same for multiple releases, so changing the behaviour now would potentially break existing applications.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15053486" author="lihy70" created="Fri, 11 Dec 2015 20:03:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;If as you said: &quot;There are even suggestions on stackoverflow to use this method for exactly that use-case&quot;, (I think that use-case you referred is: StringUtils.ordinalIndexOf(&quot;aaaaaa&quot;, &quot;aa&quot;, 2) should return 1), I agree to roll back the change to previous version.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;On the other side: &quot;This code exists since a long time and looking at the implementation it is clear what it does and what its intention is: ...&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
How long it exists doesn&apos;t mean how right it is. Definitely it does incorrectly what it&apos;s supposed to do, from my aspect.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;By the way, again, JIRA-1193 in 3.4 was broken by the wrong patch/code, not by this ticket&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15053494" author="lihy70" created="Fri, 11 Dec 2015 20:11:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;OK, basically, I think all of us agree: &quot;Furthermore the behaviour has been the same for multiple releases, so changing the behaviour now would potentially break existing applications.&quot;.&lt;br/&gt;
The discussion can be moved to how to improve this method.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15053521" author="lihy70" created="Fri, 11 Dec 2015 20:33:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;After think it about couple of minutes, I have another question: What&apos;re the general policies to fix bug/improve the code if it is not reported as bug in previous versions?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Again, I can understand and agree to roll back the changes to previous version for this case since it has been there for a long time.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1073] Read wrong component type of array in add in ArrayUtils</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1073</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-style: solid;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeHeader panelHeader&quot; style=&quot;border-bottom-width: 1px;border-bottom-style: solid;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;org.apache.commons.lang3.ArrayUtils.java&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &amp;lt;T&amp;gt; T[] add(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; T[] array, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; T element) {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Class&lt;/span&gt;&amp;lt;?&amp;gt; type;
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (array != &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;){
            type = array.getClass();
        } &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;else&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (element != &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;) {
            type = element.getClass();
        } &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;else&lt;/span&gt; {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throw&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; IllegalArgumentException(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;Arguments cannot both be &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
        }
        .......
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think it should be:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-style: solid;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeHeader panelHeader&quot; style=&quot;border-bottom-width: 1px;border-bottom-style: solid;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;org.apache.commons.lang3.ArrayUtils.java&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &amp;lt;T&amp;gt; T[] add(&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; T[] array, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; T element) {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Class&lt;/span&gt;&amp;lt;?&amp;gt; type;
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (array != &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;){
            type = array.getClass().getComponentType();
        } &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;else&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (element != &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;) {
            type = element.getClass();
        } &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;else&lt;/span&gt; {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throw&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; IllegalArgumentException(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;Arguments cannot both be &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
        }
        .......
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12759020">LANG-1073</key>
            <summary>Read wrong component type of array in add in ArrayUtils</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="kinow">Bruno P. Kinoshita</assignee>

                        <labels>
                    </labels>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14246036" author="kinow" created="Sun, 14 Dec 2014 18:27:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hello again Haiyang! Nice catch. It was working as expecting due to &lt;tt&gt;Array.newInstance&lt;/tt&gt; taking care of creating new arrays with the correct type. Furthermore, the &lt;tt&gt;public static &amp;lt;T&amp;gt; T[] add(final T[] array, final int index, final T element)&lt;/tt&gt; method uses &lt;tt&gt;.getComponentType()&lt;/tt&gt; as you suggested too.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Tested locally and all tests passed. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thank you!&lt;br/&gt;
Bruno&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1072] Duplicated &quot;0x&quot; check in createBigInteger in NumberUtils</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1072</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I think there is typo in below line:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-style: solid;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeHeader panelHeader&quot; style=&quot;border-bottom-width: 1px;border-bottom-style: solid;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;org.apache.commons.lang3.math.NumberUtils.java&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (str.startsWith(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;0x&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, pos) || str.startsWith(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;0x&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, pos)) { &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// hex
&lt;/span&gt;            radix = 16;
            pos += 2;
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The second &quot;0x&quot; should be &quot;0X&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-style: solid;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeHeader panelHeader&quot; style=&quot;border-bottom-width: 1px;border-bottom-style: solid;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;org.apache.commons.lang3.math.NumberUtils.java&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (str.startsWith(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;0x&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, pos) || str.startsWith(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;0X&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, pos)) { &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// hex
&lt;/span&gt;            radix = 16;
            pos += 2;
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>

                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1071</link>

                    <description>&lt;p&gt;StringUtils.replaceEachRepeatedly(&lt;b&gt;, *, *) has javadoc with examples of invokation of StringUtils.replaceEach(&lt;/b&gt;, *, *):&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1069] CharSet.getInstance documentation does not clearly explain how to include negation character in set</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1069</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;As discussed in &lt;a href=&quot;http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27070515/how-can-i-include-the-caret-character-in-an-apache-commons-charset&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;this Stack Overflow question&lt;/a&gt;, the documentation for &lt;tt&gt;CharSet.getInstance()&lt;/tt&gt; don&apos;t explain clearly how to include the negation character (&lt;tt&gt;^&lt;/tt&gt;) as a literal character.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The two solutions suggested in the SO question are:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// Add the &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;^&apos;&lt;/span&gt; on its own
&lt;/span&gt;CharSet.getInstance(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;^&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;otherlettershere&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);

&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// Add the &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;^&apos;&lt;/span&gt; as the last character
&lt;/span&gt;CharSet.getInstance(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;otherlettershere^&quot;&lt;/span&gt;)
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If those are the best options, we should add a line to the Javadoc to indicate this. If there is a better way, clearly that should be documented instead.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12757680">LANG-1069</key>
            <summary>CharSet.getInstance documentation does not clearly explain how to include negation character in set</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="dmjones500">Duncan Jones</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="dmjones500">Duncan Jones</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 25 Nov 2014 12:36:57 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 19 Oct 2016 07:01:25 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 11 Apr 2015 06:09:55 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.3.2</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14261389" author="anoordover" created="Tue, 30 Dec 2014 19:27:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Tried to explain corner-case usage of negating character and added unittest.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;CharSet.getInstance(&quot;^^a-d&quot;)&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;CharSet.getInstance(&quot;a-d^&quot;)&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="14328881" author="dmjones500" created="Fri, 20 Feb 2015 12:50:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Can you explain why you think &lt;tt&gt;CharSet.getInstance(&quot;^^a-d&quot;)&lt;/tt&gt; is a corner case? You&apos;ve explicitly listed it in the documentation as an example, but I don&apos;t understand why it requires special attention.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14329129" author="anoordover" created="Fri, 20 Feb 2015 16:31:27 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I tried to show with this example that parsing is executed from left to right. So the set containing a ^ is negated. The second ^ could also negate the set containing a-d and then interpreting the first ^ in some undefined way.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14490818" author="dmjones500" created="Sat, 11 Apr 2015 06:09:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the patch. I edited it a little and have now committed it:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Author: djones&lt;br/&gt;
Date: Sat Apr 11 06:02:34 2015&lt;br/&gt;
New Revision: 1672833&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/r1672833&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/r1672833&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Log:&lt;br/&gt;
Update for &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1069&quot; title=&quot;CharSet.getInstance documentation does not clearly explain how to include negation character in set&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1069&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1069&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;: CharSet.getInstance documentation does not clearly explain how to include negation character in set. Javadoc expanded and unit tests added to match examples. Based on patch by Arno Noordover.&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1064] StringUtils.abbreviate description doesn&apos;t agree with the examples</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1064</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/javadocs/api-release/org/apache/commons/lang3/StringUtils.html#abbreviate%28java.lang.String,%20int%29&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/javadocs/api-release/org/apache/commons/lang3/StringUtils.html#abbreviate%28java.lang.String,%20int%29&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;If str is less than maxWidth characters long, return it.&lt;br/&gt;
Else abbreviate it to (substring(str, 0, max-3) + &quot;...&quot;).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;
&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;StringUtils.abbreviate(&quot;abcdefg&quot;, 7) = &quot;abcdefg&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The first element of the description probably means &quot;less than or equal to&quot;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12755348">LANG-1064</key>
            <summary>StringUtils.abbreviate description doesn&apos;t agree with the examples</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="dmjones500">Duncan Jones</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bjherbison">B.J. Herbison</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 14 Nov 2014 12:06:57 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 6 Apr 2015 17:28:19 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 14 Nov 2014 12:51:50 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>3.4</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14212230" author="dmjones500" created="Fri, 14 Nov 2014 12:51:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve updated the Javadoc to read&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;If the number of characters in &lt;tt&gt;str&lt;/tt&gt; is less than or equal to &lt;tt&gt;maxWidth&lt;/tt&gt;, return &lt;tt&gt;str&lt;/tt&gt;. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks for spotting this. &lt;/p&gt;

            <title>[LANG-1061] FastDateParser error - timezones not handled correctly</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1061</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The following code throws an exception:&lt;br/&gt;
DateParser dp = FastDateFormat.getInstance(&quot;z yyyy&quot;, Locale.US);&lt;br/&gt;
dp.parse(&quot;GMT+00:00 2010&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;The format works correctly with SimpleDateFormat.&lt;/p&gt;



&lt;p&gt;Stack:&lt;br/&gt;

{0,1}
&lt;p&gt;\d&lt;/p&gt;

                            <comment id="14250431" author="sturakhia" created="Wed, 17 Dec 2014 20:04:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I would like to work on this issue. I was able to reproduce this issue on my machine. I am unable to assign it to myself though. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14252607" author="sturakhia" created="Fri, 19 Dec 2014 00:12:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I followed the instructions on this wiki  &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.apache.org/dev/git.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.apache.org/dev/git.html&lt;/a&gt; and uploaded the patch.                             <comment id="14252707" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 19 Dec 2014 01:08:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the patch.&lt;br/&gt;
However, part of the patch looks wrong:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;-            sb.append(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;(GMT[+\\-]\\d{0,1}\\d{2}|[+\\-]\\d{2}:?\\d{2}|&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
+            sb.append(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;(GMT[+\\-]\\d{0,1}\\d{2}:?\\d{2}|[+\\-]\\d{2}?\\d{2}|&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The second part of the match, i.e.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;[+\\-]\\d{2}:?\\d{2}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;has been changed to&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;[+\\-]\\d{2}?\\d{2}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This does not make sense to me - why was the colon dropped?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14252731" author="sturakhia" created="Fri, 19 Dec 2014 01:28:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks Sebb. The reason I remove it was to match the SimpleDateFormat where it supports &quot;+0000 2010&quot; for &quot;z yyyy&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
and not support &quot;+00:00 2010&quot; for &quot;z yyyy&quot; (Simple date format throws an exception for this)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Do we want to support both the formats ?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14252776" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 19 Dec 2014 01:57:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Need to look at that further, but the RE still does not make sense.&lt;br/&gt;
If support for the colon is to be dropped, then the ? needs to be removed as well, and it would become:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;[+\\-]\\d{4}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There&apos;s some other strangeness, but that was already present.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The RE&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;\\d{0,1}\\d{2}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;could be simplified to&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;\\d{2,3}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;but does it make sense to have 3 digits there?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;And does it make sense to have 3 digits followed by optional colon then another two digits? i.e. a maximum of 5 digits?&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="14262770" author="sturakhia" created="Fri, 2 Jan 2015 07:16:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks Sebb. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Regarding the first comment, I will change it to &lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt; [+\\-]\\d{4} &lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But instead of&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt; \\d{0,1}\\d{2}:?\\d{2} =&amp;gt; \\d{2,3}:?\\d{2}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think the change should be &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt; \\d{0,1}\\d{2}:?\\d{2} =&amp;gt; \\d{1,2}:?\\d{2} &lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; 

&lt;p&gt;As SimpleDateFormat also does not support the 3 digits before the colon.Please let me know what you think&lt;/p&gt;

</comment>
                            <comment id="14272195" author="sturakhia" created="Sat, 10 Jan 2015 01:15:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;~sebb@apache.org&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;,&lt;br/&gt;
       I uploaded the new patch as discussed. Please let me know what you think.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks,&lt;br/&gt;
Shweta&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14339204" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 26 Feb 2015 21:34:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t understand the patches. The latest patch (0002) does not apply properly. The original patch has some spurious changes in it.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Is there a single patch which shows the proposed changes as they are now?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14341080" author="sturakhia" created="Sat, 28 Feb 2015 00:20:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Let me  sync the repo and reapply my changes. I will send out another patch by EOD&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14341172" author="sturakhia" created="Sat, 28 Feb 2015 01:41:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;~sebb@apache.org&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;,&lt;br/&gt;
        I synced my forked repository and created the patch again. Please let me know if this patch makes sense now. Else please let me know if I am doing it wrong.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks,&lt;br/&gt;
Shweta&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14341536" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sat, 28 Feb 2015 14:13:43 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The patch is a clearer now. Still has some spurious white space changes, but can ignore those.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It will take a bit of time to review this, but it&apos;s looking good so far.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14342317" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sun, 1 Mar 2015 16:34:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It looks like the TimeZone parsing has always been wrong for both General time zone zones and RFC 822 time zones.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The current code accepts &quot;-12:34&quot; and &quot;GMT-123&quot; (which are not accepted by SDF) and does not accept &quot;GMT-12:34&quot; or &quot;GMT-1:23&quot; which are both accepted by SDF.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I agree that the colon is not allowed in the RFC 822 time zone format, and is required in the General time zone format.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14342318" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sun, 1 Mar 2015 16:41:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The latest patch uses the following RE&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;sb.append(&quot;(GMT[+\\-]\\d{0,1}\\d{2}:?\\d{2}|[+\\-]\\d{2}?\\d{2}|&quot;);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is wrong; it should be&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;sb.append(&quot;(GMT[+\\-]\\d{1,2}:?\\d{2}|[+\\-]\\d{4}|&quot;);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This was discussed previously, and is included in the 0002-patch dated 02/Jan/15.&lt;br/&gt;
It looks like the 0001-patch dated 28/Feb is not complete; it seems 0002 is needed as well.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However rather than go through the process yet again, I will make changes based on the previous discussion and the Javadoc for SimpleDateFormat.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14342356" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sun, 1 Mar 2015 18:03:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/r1663140&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/r1663140&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1060] NumberUtils.isNumber assumes number starting with Zero is octal</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1060</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The isNumber method assumes, that if the String being passed in doesn&apos;t have an &apos;X&apos; at the second char it is an octal number.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12753064">LANG-1060</key>
            <summary>NumberUtils.isNumber assumes number starting with Zero is octal</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="pascalschumacher">Pascal Schumacher</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="haugenjames">James Haugen</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 5 Nov 2014 15:22:10 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 21 Aug 2018 13:08:54 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 11 Feb 2018 11:10:34 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.3.2</version>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14198506" author="haugenjames" created="Wed, 5 Nov 2014 15:24:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In the financial industry, there are many instances of numbers that have multiple leading zeros, i.e. account ids and ssns&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15482381" author="chtompki" created="Sun, 11 Sep 2016 20:46:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Currently&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;NumberUtils.isCreatable(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;002.345&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Returns &lt;tt&gt;false&lt;/tt&gt;. I&apos;m not entirely certain how we want to fix this. I&apos;ve been working in this area, so I&apos;ll bring it up on the dev mailing list to see what people think.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

                            <comment id="16359945" author="githubbot" created="Sun, 11 Feb 2018 13:40:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;GitHub user piotrkosyoo opened a pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/314&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/314&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;
&lt;p&gt;commit 6001ce20ac49522cfd6f066b8a8bd29aab74abfb&lt;br/&gt;
Author: Piotr Kosmala &amp;lt;piotr.kosmala@...&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Date:   2018-02-10T14:19:36Z&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1060&quot; title=&quot;NumberUtils.isNumber assumes number starting with Zero is octal&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1060&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1060&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;: NumberUtils.isNumber assumes number starting with Zero is&lt;br/&gt;
    octal&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;commit 2626c00e8be29343324c755b0c4a8a56cb7dc71d&lt;br/&gt;
Author: Piotr Kosmala &amp;lt;piotr.kosmala@...&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;

    octal&lt;br/&gt;
    Update tests&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1056] StringEscapeUtils.unescapeHtml4 java.lang.IllegalArgumentException</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1056</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When I try to unescape &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; test = &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test &amp;amp;#39511154;&quot;&lt;/span&gt;;
StringEscapeUtils.unescapeHtml4(test);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I got :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
	at java.lang.Character.toChars(Character.java:4982)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.text.translate.NumericEntityUnescaper.translate(NumericEntityUnescaper.java:128)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.text.translate.AggregateTranslator.translate(AggregateTranslator.java:52)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.text.translate.CharSequenceTranslator.translate(CharSequenceTranslator.java:85)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.text.translate.CharSequenceTranslator.translate(CharSequenceTranslator.java:59)
	at org.apache.commons.lang3.StringEscapeUtils.unescapeHtml4(StringEscapeUtils.java:627)
	at unescapeHtml4Test.Main.main(Main.java:10)
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It is a bug or not? Method should return &quot;test &amp;amp;#39511154&quot; without exception or not?.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Ubuntu 64&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12750359">LANG-1056</key>
            <summary>StringEscapeUtils.unescapeHtml4 java.lang.IllegalArgumentException</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="3">Duplicate</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="dmjones500">Duncan Jones</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="Vaxx">Jakub</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 24 Oct 2014 14:26:18 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 12 Dec 2016 15:01:42 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 12 Dec 2016 15:01:42 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.3.2</version>
                                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>3</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14182854" author="dmjones500" created="Fri, 24 Oct 2014 14:54:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The Javadocs are not overly clear on this subject:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;If an entity is unrecognized, it is left alone, and inserted verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;amp;gt;&amp;amp;zzzz;x&quot; will become &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;amp;zzzz;x&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The tricky word here is &quot;unrecognized&quot;. I think &lt;tt&gt;&amp;amp;#39511154;&lt;/tt&gt; is recognised as an escaped Unicode character, but it fails during conversion. That&apos;s probably a different scenario to not &lt;em&gt;recognising&lt;/em&gt; an invalid entity like &lt;tt&gt;&amp;zzz;&lt;/tt&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I would suggest the docs are vague enough to support action in either direction. We either declare this is a bug and fix it or we decide it&apos;s good behaviour, but update the Javadocs to make it clearer this will happen.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I welcome comments from others. I think the original intention here was for no exceptions to be thrown, so I&apos;d be in favour of calling this a bug.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15655308" author="dominik.stadler@gmx.at" created="Thu, 10 Nov 2016 22:09:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This issue is actually very similar to &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TEXT-44&quot; title=&quot;NumericEntityUnescaper.translate throws an IllegalArgumentException if entityValue &amp;gt; MAX_CODE_POINT&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;TEXT-44&quot;&gt;LANG-1022&lt;/a&gt;...&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15742213" author="dmjones500" created="Mon, 12 Dec 2016 15:01:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I agree, seems an exact duplicate. I&apos;m closing it as such.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1055] StrSubstitutor.replaceSystemProperties does not work consistently</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1055</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;StrSubsitutor caches a references to SystemProperties statically on first class references.  This does not work properly with System.setProperties().  For example the following code:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;package&lt;/span&gt; test.utilities;

&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; java.util.Properties;

&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;import&lt;/span&gt; org.apache.commons.lang.text.StrSubstitutor;

&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;TestStrSubstitutor {

    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; void main(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;[] args) {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(StrSubstitutor.replaceSystemProperties(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;os.name=${os.name}&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
        Properties testProps = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; Properties();
        testProps.put(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test_key&quot;&lt;/span&gt;,  &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test_value&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
        testProps.putAll(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.getProperties());
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.setProperties(testProps);
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(StrSubstitutor.replace(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test_key=${test_key}&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.getProperties()));
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(StrSubstitutor.replaceSystemProperties(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test_key=${test_key}&quot;&lt;/span&gt;));
    }

}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;produces the following output:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;os.name=Windows 7
test_key=test_value
test_key=${test_key}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The code linked here shows the static caching of the System Properties reference: &lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/apidocs/src-html/org/apache/commons/lang3/text/StrLookup.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/apidocs/src-html/org/apache/commons/lang3/text/StrLookup.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Windows 7, Java 7&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12749765">LANG-1055</key>
            <summary>StrSubstitutor.replaceSystemProperties does not work consistently</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="britter">Benedikt Ritter</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="philci52">Phil Dicke</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 22 Oct 2014 12:59:09 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 6 Apr 2015 17:28:22 +0000</updated>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14286055" author="githubbot" created="Wed, 21 Jan 2015 18:55:06 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;GitHub user j--baker opened a pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/43&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/43&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1055&quot; title=&quot;StrSubstitutor.replaceSystemProperties does not work consistently&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1055&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1055&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;: StrLookup.systemPropertiesLookup() not singleton.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Assuming StrLookup.systemPropertiesLookup() should not be a singleton.&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Assuming each lookup should have its own snap-shot of the system properties.&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;    Please review the proposed changes.&lt;br/&gt;
    Thank you!&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    $ git pull &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/j--baker/commons-lang&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/j--baker/commons-lang&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1055&quot; title=&quot;StrSubstitutor.replaceSystemProperties does not work consistently&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1055&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1055&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/43.patch&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/43.patch&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch&lt;br/&gt;
with (at least) the following in the commit message:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    This closes #43&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;
&lt;p&gt;commit f4d574872bdd488032b296faece7921737518c3a&lt;br/&gt;
Author: j-&lt;del&gt;baker &amp;lt;j&lt;/del&gt;-baker@users.noreply.github.com&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Date:   2015-01-21T18:45:11Z&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1055&quot; title=&quot;StrSubstitutor.replaceSystemProperties does not work consistently&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1055&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1055&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;: Change StrLookup.systemPropertiesLookup() to return a new instance with its own copy of the current system properties.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;hr /&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14286057" author="jbaker" created="Wed, 21 Jan 2015 18:56:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Not sure if this is correct, or if it addresses Phil&apos;s concerns, but the following is an implementation that 1) does not use a singleton, and 2) allows each instance to have their own snap-shop of the system properties:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/43&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/43&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks in advance for your time.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14287067" author="britter" created="Thu, 22 Jan 2015 07:42:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Setting this to review patch. I&apos;ll try to have a look soon.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14288951" author="githubbot" created="Fri, 23 Jan 2015 08:11:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Github user asfgit closed the pull request at:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/43&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/43&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14288953" author="britter" created="Fri, 23 Jan 2015 08:11:43 +0000"  >&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;$ svn ci -m &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;LANG-1055: StrSubstitutor.replaceSystemProperties does not work consistently. This fixes #43 from github. Thanks to Jonathan Baker.&quot;&lt;/span&gt; src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/text/StrLookup.java src/test/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/text/StrLookupTest.java
Sending        src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/text/StrLookup.java
Sending        src/test/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/text/StrLookupTest.java
Transmitting file data ..
Committed revision 1654134.
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1049] SerializationUtils.deserialize() can not be used within OSGi</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1049</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;SerializationUtils.deserialize() throws a SerializationException if objects should be deserialized that can not be resolved by OSGi classloader of org.apache.commons.lang bundle.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To solve this problem I suggest to allow buddy classloading within commons.lang to allow other bundles to register their class loaders.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please add&lt;br/&gt;
Eclipse-BuddyPolicy: registered&lt;br/&gt;
to the MANIFEST.MF of commons.lang to solve this problem.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Equinox&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12748032">LANG-1049</key>
            <summary>SerializationUtils.deserialize() can not be used within OSGi</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/reopened.png" description="This issue was once resolved, but the resolution was deemed incorrect. From here issues are either marked assigned or resolved.">Reopened</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="marcus.klein">Marcus Klein</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 14 Oct 2014 13:32:28 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 22 Oct 2016 13:51:31 +0000</updated>
                                            <version>2.6</version>
                                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>1</votes>
                                    <watches>5</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14171711" author="joehni" created="Tue, 14 Oct 2014 23:34:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It does not make sense to add Eclipse-specific entries to the manifest, sorry.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, we actually should provide a deserialize method that take an additional ClassLoader argument which is used in a custom ObjectInputStream that overwrites resolveClass:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/io/ObjectInputStream.html#resolveClass(java.io.ObjectStreamClass)&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/io/ObjectInputStream.html#resolveClass(java.io.ObjectStreamClass)&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14172108" author="marcus.klein" created="Wed, 15 Oct 2014 07:43:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I was not aware of these new methods for object deserialization. But I agree to use these methods instead of Eclipse-specific extensions.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14328887" author="dmjones500" created="Fri, 20 Feb 2015 13:03:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=marcus.klein&quot; class=&quot;user-hover&quot; rel=&quot;marcus.klein&quot;&gt;Marcus Klein&lt;/a&gt;: do you think this issue should become a feature request, asking for what Joerg describes? Or are you happy that we close this, because you have found an alternative option?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14328922" author="marcus.klein" created="Fri, 20 Feb 2015 13:41:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;My alternative option is currently NOT to use SerializationUtils.deserialize(). In my eyes this is not an alternative option.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please add as feature request, what Joerg describes. But I personally don&apos;t see this as a feature request. The purpose of org.apache.commons.lang is to provide utilities for easier Java coding. Furthermore org.apache.commons.lang is exposed as being compatible with OSGi. But as described here, the utility is not usable in OSGi because of framework/classloader restrictions. If org.apache.commons.lang would not be exposed as OSGi compatible, this would be a feature request, of course. In this case it is a bug.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14328932" author="dmjones500" created="Fri, 20 Feb 2015 13:52:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Understood. I propose we leave this as it is then, since the comment thread explains the direction we wish to go.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Patches welcome for &lt;tt&gt;SerializationUtils.deserialize()&lt;/tt&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14981501" author="chris@die-schneider.net" created="Thu, 29 Oct 2015 22:48:58 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I found the class org.apache.commons.io.input.ClassLoaderObjectInputStream in commons-io. Using this class it should be easy to implement this. To not create a new dependency we could copy the code over? WDYT?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14982077" author="marcus.klein" created="Fri, 30 Oct 2015 07:47:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t remember where we needed this. Closing for now.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14982083" author="chris@die-schneider.net" created="Fri, 30 Oct 2015 07:51:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Strange timing to close the issue as soon as I propose a fix. Should I open a new issue?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14982098" author="marcus.klein" created="Fri, 30 Oct 2015 08:11:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;First you told me, that you don&apos;t want to implement this. Then you ignored this issue for a whole year. Are you sure, that somebody can wait in this agile world to get something solved for a whole year?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;We solved the problem in October 2014 by using plain Java:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;byte[] bytes = reader.readByteArray();&lt;br/&gt;
bais = new ByteArrayInputStream(bytes);&lt;br/&gt;
ois = new ObjectInputStream(bais);&lt;br/&gt;
Object object = ois.readObject();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This even works in OSGi, because the ClassLoader of the ObjectInputStream is aware of the classes to deserialize because we use for that bundle buddy class loading. Replacing this four lines with SerializationUtils.deserialize() is no convenience any more when class loading kludge is needed. Sorry.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14982110" author="chris@die-schneider.net" created="Fri, 30 Oct 2015 08:17:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I can imagine your frustration. I am no committer on commons-lang though. I will open a new issue and see if it gets some attention.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14982120" author="joehni" created="Fri, 30 Oct 2015 08:20:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Just because you found an Eclipse-specific solution does not mean that the issue is solved.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14982123" author="joehni" created="Fri, 30 Oct 2015 08:21:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Don&apos;t. This is the correct issue.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
