<item>
            <title>[LANG-1004] DurationFormatUtils#formatDurationHMS implementation does not correspond to Javadoc and vice versa</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1004</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;This method has several flaws:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1. Javadoc says: &quot;The format used is ISO8601-like: H:m:s.S.&quot; but the method call supplies &quot;H:mm:ss.SSS&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
2. ISO time never omits leading zeros, so the proper pattern must be &quot;HH:mm:ss.SSS&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
3. The method name says: &quot;HMS&quot; but includes the second fraction.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Since the use of fractions is optional, the method should use &quot;HH:mm:ss&quot; and update the Javadoc as well.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12711585">LANG-1004</key>
            <summary>DurationFormatUtils#formatDurationHMS implementation does not correspond to Javadoc and vice versa</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="britter">Benedikt Ritter</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="michael-o">Michael Osipov</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 30 Apr 2014 21:11:43 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 6 Apr 2015 17:28:22 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 4 Aug 2014 12:24:59 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.3.2</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.4</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.text.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13987660" author="michael-o" created="Fri, 2 May 2014 13:12:16 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Benedikt. have a look at the patch.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13987919" author="britter" created="Fri, 2 May 2014 17:07:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi Michael,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;nice patch! However I&apos;m a bit afraid this change will break clients that are using the method as it is now. What do you think? The main use case is probably formatting for displaying a value (in the GUI or in some kind of log file). So it may not be a problem?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Benedikt&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;EDIT: how about providing a new method called &lt;tt&gt;formatDurationISOHMS&lt;/tt&gt; which formats the way you propose?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13988341" author="michael-o" created="Fri, 2 May 2014 22:21:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I guess you are right about the usecase but we &lt;b&gt;cannot&lt;/b&gt; do assumptions about the client. So the impact should be minimal. In this case, we should stick to &lt;tt&gt;HH:mm:ss.SSS&lt;/tt&gt; and improve the docs. However, we could spawn another ticket for Lang 4 to split method into two methods, one for &lt;tt&gt;HH:mm:ss&lt;/tt&gt; and one &lt;tt&gt;formatDurationHMSwithFrac&lt;/tt&gt; or something like this (maybe a boolean flag) which will use &lt;tt&gt;HH:mm:ss.SSS&lt;/tt&gt;. Same applies for the ISO duration of course.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I wouldn&apos;t bloat the API with another method but I would rather add something like I did for &lt;a href=&quot;https://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MNG-5176?focusedCommentId=340413&amp;amp;page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-340413&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;MNG-5176&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13988347" author="michael-o" created="Fri, 2 May 2014 22:25:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Have a look at the new patch.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13988950" author="britter" created="Sun, 4 May 2014 09:29:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hello Michael, &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;After applying your patch I get two test failures:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;Failed tests: 
  StopWatchTest.testStopWatchSimpleGet:55 expected:&amp;lt;0[]:00:00.000&amp;gt; but was:&amp;lt;0[0]:00:00.000&amp;gt;
  StopWatchTest.testStopWatchSplit:76 Formatted split string not the correct length expected:&amp;lt;12&amp;gt; but was:&amp;lt;11&amp;gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Those two test cases fail because StopWatch uses DurationFormatUtils internally. You will have to update the tests as well &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;TIA!&lt;br/&gt;
Benedikt&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1003] DurationFormatUtils are not able to handle negative durations/periods</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1003</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;It spits out complete garbage.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(DurationFormatUtils.formatDurationHMS(-3454));
&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;System&lt;/span&gt;.out.println(DurationFormatUtils.formatPeriodISO(4000, 3000));
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;0:00:-3.-454
P-1Y11M30DT23H59M59.000S
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It should throw an &lt;tt&gt;IllegalArgumentException&lt;/tt&gt; if duration is &amp;lt; 0 or period diff is &amp;lt; 0.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12711581">LANG-1003</key>
            <summary>DurationFormatUtils are not able to handle negative durations/periods</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="2" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/critical.svg">Critical</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="britter">Benedikt Ritter</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="michael-o">Michael Osipov</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 30 Apr 2014 21:02:43 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 6 Apr 2015 17:28:24 +0000</updated>

                                    <fixVersion>3.4</fixVersion>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1002] Several predefined ISO FastDateFormats in DateFormatUtils are incorrect</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1002</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Formats &lt;tt&gt;ISO_TIME_FORMAT&lt;/tt&gt;, &lt;tt&gt;ISO_TIME_TIME_ZONE_FORMAT&lt;/tt&gt; prepend a &lt;tt&gt;T&lt;/tt&gt; but this is not correct. Sole time is never prepended by defintion. &lt;tt&gt;T&lt;/tt&gt; is used only when date &lt;b&gt;and&lt;/b&gt; time are given.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The Javadocs of &lt;tt&gt;ISO_TIME_NO_T_FORMAT&lt;/tt&gt;, &lt;tt&gt;ISO_TIME_NO_T_FORMAT&lt;/tt&gt; are in correct too because they say: &quot;This pattern does not comply with the formal ISO8601 specification as the standard requires the &apos;T&apos; prefix for times.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You might want to read &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~mgk25/iso-time.html#time&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;Markus Kuhn&apos;s reference&lt;/a&gt; on that.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A solution would be remove the first two and rename the second two by dropping the &lt;tt&gt;NO_T&lt;/tt&gt; in the name.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12711574">LANG-1002</key>
            <summary>Several predefined ISO FastDateFormats in DateFormatUtils are incorrect</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="chonton">Charles Honton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="michael-o">Michael Osipov</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 30 Apr 2014 20:45:25 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 19 Oct 2016 07:00:29 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 8 Jul 2015 05:51:13 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.3.2</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.5</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.time.*</component>
                        <due></due>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13986146" author="garydgregory" created="Wed, 30 Apr 2014 21:58:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Very odd indeed. The intent is clearly documented in the unit test. So this is just completely wrong. Changing it would break runtime compatibility but what else to do? Create new contants with no T&apos;s calls ISO8601_.... instead of ISO...?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13986456" author="michael-o" created="Thu, 1 May 2014 08:44:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Gary, I fail to find the intent here: &lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/xref-test/org/apache/commons/lang3/time/DateFormatUtilsTest.html#L154&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/xref-test/org/apache/commons/lang3/time/DateFormatUtilsTest.html#L154&lt;/a&gt;. To which intent are you referring?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13986508" author="michael-o" created="Thu, 1 May 2014 11:21:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Gary, I think we can do the following here to minimize impact.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1. Create a new ticket which will address the entire problem in Commons Lang 4 cleanly, i.e., remove &lt;tt&gt;NO_T&lt;/tt&gt; formats and make the other formats correct.&lt;br/&gt;
2. Lang 3 has to remain as-is &amp;#8211; unfortunately, but we deprecate can &lt;tt&gt;NO_T&lt;/tt&gt; formats and change the Javadocs of the others saying that the format will change in 4.0.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Introducing new constants like &lt;tt&gt;ISO_8601_...&lt;/tt&gt; would require do add them for all formats to have a uniform use. I think this is overhead.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;What do you think?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14592477" author="michael-o" created="Thu, 18 Jun 2015 20:42:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;~garydgregory&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;, it has been already more than a year. I&apos;d like to finalize this issue now. Please read my previous comment.&lt;br/&gt;
I&apos;d like to remove all invalid static patterns in 4.0 and deprecate them in 3.x.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14596394" author="britter" created="Mon, 22 Jun 2015 18:35:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;without getting into the details here, I think we should:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;provide constants with the correct values&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;provide additional constants the differ from the standards constants if they are useful.&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Deprecating incorrect constants to remove them later on is okay to me. Changes the value of incorrect constants and document this in the RELEASE-NOTES is also okay to me.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14618237" author="michael-o" created="Wed, 8 Jul 2015 08:52:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Charles, you might want to set the fix version. The change looks fine.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14877226" author="michael-o" created="Sat, 19 Sep 2015 17:46:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Recently looked at the commit and some note about it. The naming &lt;tt&gt;ISO8601_...&lt;/tt&gt; isn&apos;t quite good because it is ISO 8601 and &lt;b&gt;not&lt;/b&gt; ISO8601. Thus, it should be &lt;tt&gt;ISO_8601_...&lt;/tt&gt;. If no one really opposes, I would add a subsequent commit which fixes that.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14905475" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Wed, 23 Sep 2015 23:09:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Are these new constants?&lt;br/&gt;

            <title>[LANG-1001] ISO 8601 misspelled throughout the Javadocs</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1001</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The Javadocs say: &lt;tt&gt;ISO8601&lt;/tt&gt; but the correct format is &lt;tt&gt;ISO 8601&lt;/tt&gt;. Note the space.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A patch can be provided.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-1000] ParseException when trying to parse UTC dates with Z as zone designator using DateFormatUtils.ISO_DATETIME_TIME_ZONE_FORMAT</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1000</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I have the &lt;tt&gt;String&lt;/tt&gt; &lt;tt&gt;2013-11-18T12:48:05Z&lt;/tt&gt; which I want to parse into a &lt;tt&gt;Date&lt;/tt&gt; using &lt;tt&gt;DateFormatUtils.ISO_DATETIME_TIME_ZONE_FORMAT&lt;/tt&gt;. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;According to &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#UTC&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#UTC&lt;/a&gt; the &lt;tt&gt;Z&lt;/tt&gt; at the end should be a valid abbreviation for &lt;tt&gt;UTC+00:00&lt;/tt&gt; (or &lt;tt&gt;UTC&lt;/tt&gt;) and so all should be fine.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But when I am trying to do so I get the following exception:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;java.text.ParseException: Unparseable date: &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;2013-11-18T12:48:05Z&quot;&lt;/span&gt; does not match
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12711456">LANG-1000</key>
            <summary>ParseException when trying to parse UTC dates with Z as zone designator using DateFormatUtils.ISO_DATETIME_TIME_ZONE_FORMAT</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="dmjones500">Duncan Jones</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="host">Holger Stenzhorn</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 30 Apr 2014 12:55:19 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 6 Apr 2015 17:28:17 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 28 Sep 2014 10:12:41 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.3.2</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.4</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="14151003" author="dmjones500" created="Sun, 28 Sep 2014 06:30:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m able to reproduce this too. It seems that &quot;ZZ&quot; has no special meaning within the parser classes, despite the Javadoc promising the contrary. In &lt;tt&gt;FastDateParser.getStrategy()&lt;/tt&gt;, only the first &apos;z&apos; is noticed and a general timezone strategy is returned.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As a side note, as and when we move to Java 7 as the minimum supported API, we can use the new &quot;X&quot; pattern letter, which is designed for ISO 8601 time zones.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In the meantime, I&apos;ll see what can be done in the current API. A work-around for now is to substitute &quot;+00:00&quot; for &quot;Z&quot; in the input date, prior to parsing.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14151066" author="dmjones500" created="Sun, 28 Sep 2014 10:12:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Author: djones&lt;br/&gt;
Date: Sun Sep 28 10:11:17 2014&lt;br/&gt;
New Revision: 1628061&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/r1628061&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/r1628061&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Log:&lt;br/&gt;
Added missing support for ISO 8601 parsing and printing using &quot;ZZ&quot; pattern (code now matches Javadoc). Addresses &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-1000&quot; title=&quot;ParseException when trying to parse UTC dates with Z as zone designator using DateFormatUtils.ISO_DATETIME_TIME_ZONE_FORMAT&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-1000&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-1000&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Modified:&lt;br/&gt;
    commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/changes/changes.xml&lt;br/&gt;
    commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/time/FastDateParser.java&lt;br/&gt;
    commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/time/FastDatePrinter.java&lt;br/&gt;
    commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/test/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/time/DateFormatUtilsTest.java&lt;br/&gt;
    commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/test/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/time/FastDatePrinterTest.java&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

    </item>


<item>
            <title>[LANG-997] NumberUtil#isNumber() returns false for &quot;012345678&quot; but not for &quot;12345678&quot;</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-997</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;With commons-lang 3.2.1:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;boolean&lt;/span&gt; ret = NumberUtils.isNumber( &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;012345678901234567&quot;&lt;/span&gt; );
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; 

&lt;p&gt;returns &lt;tt&gt;true&lt;/tt&gt;, but for 3.3.2, returns &lt;tt&gt;false&lt;/tt&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The change seems to be introduced in &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-972&quot; title=&quot;NumberUtils#isNumber does not allow for hex 0XABCD&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-972&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-972&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; / &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-992&quot; title=&quot;NumberUtils#isNumber() returns false for &amp;quot;0.0&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;0.4790&amp;quot;, et al&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-992&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-992&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;, as it seems to consider now that, if the parameter string has a leading 0, and it&apos;s not hex, then it must be forcibly octal.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As previous 3.x versions accept 0ddd as valid decimal numbers, the suggested change on NumberUtils#isNumber, is to replace lines &lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/xref/org/apache/commons/lang3/math/NumberUtils.html#L1367&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;1367-1376&lt;/a&gt; with:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;           } &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;else&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Character&lt;/span&gt;.isDigit(chars[start + 1])) {
               &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// leading 0, but not hex, must be octal or decimal
&lt;/span&gt;               &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; i = start + 1;
               &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; (; i &amp;lt; chars.length; i++) {
                   &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (chars[i] &amp;lt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;0&apos;&lt;/span&gt; || chars[i] &amp;gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;9&apos;&lt;/span&gt;) { &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// was: &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (chars[i] &amp;lt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;0&apos;&lt;/span&gt; || chars[i] &amp;gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&apos;7&apos;&lt;/span&gt;) {
&lt;/span&gt;                       &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt;;
                   }
               }
               &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;true&lt;/span&gt;; 
           }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Java 6&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12709554">LANG-997</key>
            <summary>NumberUtil#isNumber() returns false for &quot;012345678&quot; but not for &quot;12345678&quot;</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="8">Not A Problem</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="juanpablo">Juan Pablo Santos Rodr&#237;guez</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 21 Apr 2014 14:27:11 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 28 May 2016 16:22:53 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 2 Jun 2014 19:08:58 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.3.2</version>
                                                    <component>lang.math.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>4</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13980974" author="britter" created="Fri, 25 Apr 2014 13:22:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Should be in the next release. Setting to 3.4.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13981715" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Fri, 25 Apr 2014 22:38:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m not sure we want to implement this.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;At present, isNumber() agrees with Java constant syntax and the createNumber() method in treating a leading 0 as meaning octal.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If leading zero is ignored, then isNumber() won&apos;t agree with createNumber() or Java.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think the current behaviour should be kept (and documented more thoroughly if need be).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If there is a need to allow leading zeros, this could perhaps be done with a new method - or by adding a second boolean parameter to select the new behaviour.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13981869" author="bayard" created="Sat, 26 Apr 2014 04:02:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Summarizing - the issue isn&apos;t that 0123 is bad, but that 012345678901234567 is too big for Java.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In the same way, 0xfffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffff should return false. It currently returns true.&lt;br/&gt;
Also 9e99999999999999999999 is too large, but returns true currently.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m +1 to considering this a regression and accepting an isNumber that can handle numbers larger than Java is prepared to handle. ie) Fixing this bug.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13981928" author="britter" created="Sat, 26 Apr 2014 09:00:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;isNumber returns a boolean, but it looks like we want to give more than two answers:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;the given input is &lt;b&gt;not&lt;/b&gt; a number&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;the given input is a valid number in java&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;the given input is a number, but it is to big for Java to handle it&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;The question is: what would you do with the last information? The is no way to process the string literal passed into the method, because you simply cannot convert it to a number in Java. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;How about introducing a second method &lt;tt&gt;isJavaNumber&lt;/tt&gt; or something like that?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13981930" author="juanpablo" created="Sat, 26 Apr 2014 09:19:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi, &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;the issue isn&apos;t only with &quot;too big&quot; numbers, f.ex., &quot;01258&quot; also returns false. Consider this code:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;@Test
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void isNumber() {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Number&lt;/span&gt; n = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Integer&lt;/span&gt;( &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;01258&quot;&lt;/span&gt; ); &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;//  notice we&apos;re using a &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;, as NumberUtil.isNumber does, trying to use 01258 without quotes results in a compilation error
&lt;/span&gt;        Assert.assertTrue( n.intValue() == 1258 );
        n = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Integer&lt;/span&gt;( &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;Unicorn&quot;&lt;/span&gt; ) &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// -&amp;gt; NFException, expect NumberUtils.isNumber to &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;false&lt;/span&gt; here, as it does
&lt;/span&gt;}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I expect isNumber to return true; Furthermore, it was returning true before 3.3.x.. Agree with the isJavaNumber method need instead of changing behaviour.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13982060" author="b.eckenfels" created="Sat, 26 Apr 2014 18:21:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Juan, the problem is that &quot;0&quot; prefix is detected as an octal number. In that case it only allows digits from 0-7, so 077 is ok but 088 is not.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think this method is not really useful as it does not define what numbers it will accept. It should differentiate between integers and floats and between encoded and consitent (decimal) encoding. And for the encoded form, it needs to spell out the syntax supported. For example &quot;0&quot; and &quot;0x&quot; and &quot;#&quot; for Integer.decode(). Integer.parseInt(&quot;012&quot;) -&amp;gt; 12. Integer. Integer.decode(&quot;012&quot;) -&amp;gt; 10. It also needs to support different value ranges. I think the most common usage of this is to guard any of the parse/decode methods, so there should be a 1:1 acceptor.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13983713" author="juanpablo" created="Mon, 28 Apr 2014 23:10:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi Bernd,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;saw the octal issue, but my concern was that NumberUtils on 3.2.1 was returning true for, i.e., &quot;018&quot; and now is returning false, considering that &quot;018&quot; is a valid number. I expected for this method the same behaviour you described at &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-992?focusedCommentId=13949713&amp;amp;page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-13949713&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;LANG-992&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Actually my expectation for using that method would be that &quot;isNumber returns true if I can use it without a NumberFormatException with Integer.parseInt(String) or Double.parseDouble(String)&quot;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I expected that &quot;018&quot; was recognized as a valid number, because as it can be used as new Integer( &quot;018&quot; ), without any NFExceptions, it made sense to me that it was recognized as a valid Java number, hence isNumber( &quot;018&quot; ) should return true. Then went into &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-971&quot; title=&quot;NumberUtils#isNumber(String) fails to reject invalid Octal numbers&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-971&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-971&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; issue link and and saw that this is not the method intention. I found it a bit surprising.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;We&apos;ve been using this method to check if some fixed-width values were &quot;numbers&quot; or not (as in behaviour described on the quote above), and when upgrading suddenly a lot of tests began to fail because of this change. Seems we&apos;ll have to seek for a workaround if we want to upgrade this library. It&apos;d be fine for me if at least the javadocs would give a more precise description regarding the scope of the method or, maybe some examples of the method outcomes on the method&apos;s javadoc (as it&apos;s done on StringUtils, f.ex).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13991149" author="dmjones500" created="Tue, 6 May 2014 21:17:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=juanpablo&quot; class=&quot;user-hover&quot; rel=&quot;juanpablo&quot;&gt;Juan Pablo Santos Rodr&#237;guez&lt;/a&gt;: have you considered &lt;tt&gt;isDigits()&lt;/tt&gt;?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve also updated the Javadoc to better describe octal handling:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;Non-hexadecimal strings beginning with a leading zero are treated as octal values. Thus the string 09 will return false, since 9 is not a valid octal value.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13991193" author="juanpablo" created="Tue, 6 May 2014 21:52:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi Duncan,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;isDigits()&lt;/tt&gt; returns false for &quot;3.4&quot;, while the old &lt;tt&gt;isNumber&lt;/tt&gt; is returning true.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I was looking for something along the lines &lt;tt&gt;toDouble(String)&lt;/tt&gt; / &lt;tt&gt;toLong(String)&lt;/tt&gt; etc., but returning &lt;tt&gt;true&lt;/tt&gt; / &lt;tt&gt;false&lt;/tt&gt; while avoiding at the same time the &lt;tt&gt;try/catch(NumberFormatException)&lt;/tt&gt; of those methods. Seeing that 09 is meant to be false for &lt;tt&gt;isNumber&lt;/tt&gt;, is there any chance to add a new method with that functionality?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;thx + br&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13991776" author="dmjones500" created="Wed, 7 May 2014 12:26:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=juanpablo&quot; class=&quot;user-hover&quot; rel=&quot;juanpablo&quot;&gt;Juan Pablo Santos Rodr&#237;guez&lt;/a&gt;: Feel free to raise a new issue that describes your desired functionality.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Can we now considered this issue closed, on the basis that &lt;tt&gt;isNumber&lt;/tt&gt; considers &lt;tt&gt;&quot;012345678901234567&quot;&lt;/tt&gt; an octal number and that v3.2.1 was broken?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14002325" author="juanpablo" created="Mon, 19 May 2014 20:23:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi Duncan,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;apologies on getting to his late, apparently I didn&apos;t received the mail associated to your last comment. Please feel free to close the issue, as it seems clear that the intention of &lt;tt&gt;isNumber&lt;/tt&gt; is to consider 018 as not a number. Will open a new issue to ask for the desired functionality.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;thanks,&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14015747" author="britter" created="Mon, 2 Jun 2014 19:08:58 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Closing as not a problem.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-996] FastDateFormat is case sensitive</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-996</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;It seems that &lt;tt&gt;FastDateFormat&lt;/tt&gt; is case sensitive. But it claims to be mostly compatible with &lt;tt&gt;SimpleDateFormat&lt;/tt&gt; which is not.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For example, this throws a &lt;tt&gt;ParseException&lt;/tt&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;FastDateFormat.getInstance(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;dd-MMM-yyyy&quot;&lt;/span&gt;).parse(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;01-jan-2000&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But these do not:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;SimpleDateFormat sdf = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; SimpleDateFormat(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;dd-MMM-yyyy&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
sdf.parse(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;01-jan-2000&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
DateUtils.parse(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;01-jan-2000&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;dd-MMM-yyyy&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12707939">LANG-996</key>
            <summary>FastDateFormat is case sensitive</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="chonton">Charles Honton</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="drees">David Rees</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 11 Apr 2014 13:45:41 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 6 Apr 2015 17:28:15 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 23 Apr 2014 16:05:23 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.3.2</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.4</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.time.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>4</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13966546" author="britter" created="Fri, 11 Apr 2014 14:17:43 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;d like to have this fixed in 3.4&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13976012" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Mon, 21 Apr 2014 20:43:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Looks like this will need a new version of the TextStrategy that supports case-blind matching.&lt;br/&gt;
This could perhaps be done by converting the month strings to lower case in the map; then converting the input value to lowercase before looking up the map.&lt;br/&gt;
The Locale is known when creating a Strategy, however it is not provided when parsing using the setCalendar method.&lt;br/&gt;
The Strategy interface is private, so it would be possible to change the setCalendar method to pass in the Locale.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13976039" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Mon, 21 Apr 2014 21:09:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;That&apos;s not sufficient - the generated regex also needs to be case-blind&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13978362" author="charles_honton@intuit.com" created="Wed, 23 Apr 2014 16:05:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;commit 1589446&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13978376" author="drees" created="Wed, 23 Apr 2014 16:12:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the quick work guys, looking forward to using this in the next release. &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14226149" author="pishty" created="Wed, 26 Nov 2014 13:04:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;hello guys, is there a snapshot jar where i can get this fix from, i have looked for it but couldnt find it.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14226700" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Wed, 26 Nov 2014 19:38:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Snapshots are published to the ASF SNAPSHOT repository.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The URL is in the Apache Parent POM; just make sure you enable use of the repo &quot;apache.snapshots.https&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Note that SNAPSHOTS are automated builds, and have not been reviewed by Commons developers.&lt;br/&gt;
Use at your own risk.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-992] NumberUtils#isNumber() returns false for &quot;0.0&quot;, &quot;0.4790&quot;, et al</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-992</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;After upgrading from 3.1 to 3.3.1, it seems that &lt;tt&gt;isNumber(String str)&lt;/tt&gt; returns false for decimal numbers with leading zeros. In other words:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;boolean&lt;/span&gt; ret = NumberUtils.isNumber(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;0.4790&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;On 3.1, &lt;tt&gt;ret&lt;/tt&gt; was true. In 3.3.1, &lt;tt&gt;ret&lt;/tt&gt; is false.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Guessing that &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-972&quot; title=&quot;NumberUtils#isNumber does not allow for hex 0XABCD&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-972&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-972&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; is related... comment in the code states:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// leading 0, but not hex, must be octal&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is clearly a case where leading 0 means neither hex nor octal.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Java 8, Windows 7&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12703833">LANG-992</key>
            <summary>NumberUtils#isNumber() returns false for &quot;0.0&quot;, &quot;0.4790&quot;, et al</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="5">Cannot Reproduce</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="chtompki">Rob Tompkins</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="adam@labkey.com">Adam Rauch</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 26 Mar 2014 21:26:22 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 19 Oct 2016 15:24:37 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sun, 11 Sep 2016 20:41:37 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.3.1</version>
                                                    <component>lang.math.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>2</votes>
                                    <watches>8</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13948745" author="niallp" created="Thu, 27 Mar 2014 01:49:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Yes, this was caused by the second commit for &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-972&quot; title=&quot;NumberUtils#isNumber does not allow for hex 0XABCD&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-972&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-972&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;  in revision 1566967 when the change for Octal numbers was made. I have a patch that resolves this specific issue, but perhaps the Octal change should be reverted.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13948763" author="niallp" created="Thu, 27 Mar 2014 02:04:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Attaching second version of patch&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13948961" author="dmjones500" created="Thu, 27 Mar 2014 06:55:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=niallp&quot; class=&quot;user-hover&quot; rel=&quot;niallp&quot;&gt;Niall Pemberton&lt;/a&gt;: your patch looks good. I see no reason to revert the octal change, just a shame we hadn&apos;t already captured this case in a unit test. Do you intend to commit your patch?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13949221" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 27 Mar 2014 12:27:43 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Should octal numbers be validated or not?&lt;br/&gt;
Clearly a number such as 0xdefgh is invalid, because the 0x prefix unambiguosly identifies a hex number.&lt;br/&gt;
However 0123 is potentially equally valid as an octal and a decimal number. &lt;br/&gt;
Which is correct depends on the context.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Now the Javadoc for isNumber says &quot;Checks whether the String a valid Java number.&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
If we take that to mean that the digit string must be valid as a numeric Java literal, then clearly the leading 0 means octal.&lt;br/&gt;
However, numeric literals are not Strings.&lt;br/&gt;
JVM methods such as Integer.decode(String) that treat a leading 0 as meaning octal will reject a parameter that contains non-octal digits - so again that suggests octal should be validated.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As far as I know, there are no standard Java methods that accept number type suffixes in Strings.&lt;br/&gt;
I think these are only accepted in numeric literals.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The fact that isNumber() accepts all these formats leads me to the conclusion that the intention was probably to support the same syntax as Java literals, and so the code should validate octal numbers accordingly.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13949713" author="b.eckenfels" created="Thu, 27 Mar 2014 18:00:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Actually my expectation for using that method would be that &quot;isNumber returns true if I can use it without a NumberFormatException with Integer.parseInt(String) or Double.parseDouble(String)&quot;. Because the Java syntax and literal format is not really something which you use anywhere outside the compiler/source tools.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, I would be fine with both definitions, as long as they are added to the javadoc comment.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;BTW1: I have some applications where the NFE is a major slow down as I use the parse function to validate. So I do see a big reason for having a boolean validate function.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;BTW2: I think hex/ocatal prefixes and decimal digits are never seen in the same function, so I think having a &quot;isInteger()&quot; which knows about octal/hex and having a isNumber() which fails on hex and ignores trailing 0 would be a more logical thing.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13949781" author="rahook" created="Thu, 27 Mar 2014 18:49:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is a show-stopper for us - I can revert to 3.1 for the project that is affected, however need to retain 3.3.1 for other projects.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13949840" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 27 Mar 2014 19:37:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;@Bernd&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The isNumber() method currently also allows &quot;0xABCD&quot; and &quot;27L&quot; which are not allowed by the parseTTT() methods - it is not just the octal validation that would cause problems.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I think one would need several new methods to validate strings intended for parse functions.&lt;br/&gt;
In your case I would have thought a Regular Expression matcher would be suitable.&lt;br/&gt;
I suggest you create a JIRA enhancement request with details of your use-cases.&lt;br/&gt;
Note that Commons Validator provides lots of Numeric validation routines already - that may be a better solution.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13950314" author="niallp" created="Fri, 28 Mar 2014 03:11:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I have checked in the change in revision 1582585&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13991456" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Wed, 7 May 2014 01:25:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;What about 01.23 etc?&lt;br/&gt;
This will be allowed by createNumber().&lt;br/&gt;
Maybe the check for &quot;.&quot; should scan the entire string.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14167898" author="jamessawle" created="Sat, 11 Oct 2014 01:08:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is a possible large refactor of the isNumber functionality extracting each of the different datatypes into their own methods. Whilst this will not be as efficient as the original method, it is more maintainable and would allow for the possibility of making each of them public separately.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I understand that this may be a step to far, but would be interested in hearing people&apos;s views. This does not however, cover Sebb&apos;s point about 01.23 as I do not believe that createNumber should be allowing it.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If this is liked, javadoc and separate testing of each function can be added (make the method package private).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15434717" author="mj.mahmoudi@yahoo.com" created="Wed, 24 Aug 2016 11:10:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m starter for contribute this project and not good familiar with flow of issues. &lt;br/&gt;
I see this issue resolved in version 3.4, I say correct?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15449975" author="pascalschumacher" created="Tue, 30 Aug 2016 19:57:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It was marked as fixed in 3.3.2, but then reopened and not closed again. So the issue remains unresolved.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15451342" author="mj.mahmoudi@yahoo.com" created="Wed, 31 Aug 2016 06:41:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks for your reply but When do this issue close?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15453122" author="pascalschumacher" created="Wed, 31 Aug 2016 19:20:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Commons is completely volunteer based. Issues are closed when somebody contributes a fix. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="15482371" author="chtompki" created="Sun, 11 Sep 2016 20:41:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I could not reproduce this issue in the release candidate for 3.5 with java 1.6 or java 1.7.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-991] Release notes cannot display special characters</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-991</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When viewing &lt;a href=&quot;http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/release-notes/RELEASE-NOTES-3.3.1.txt&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;the release notes&lt;/a&gt; online, special characters in some contributors names are not showing correctly.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;E.g. search for:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;o LANG-951:  Fragments are wrong by 1 day when using fragment YEAR or MONTH.
             Thanks to Sebastian G&#65533;tz.
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;d guess we need to change the Maven resource encoding for this file, although I&apos;ve not yet had time to poke at the problem in any great detail.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>

            <title>[LANG-988] Where&apos;s the user guide?</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-988</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The homepage claims &quot;A getting started user guide is available together with various project reports.&quot; The link for the user guide (&lt;a href=&quot;https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/userguide.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/userguide.html&lt;/a&gt;) then says &quot;Looking for the User Guide? It has been moved to the package JavaDoc&quot; - and the JavaDoc link points to the javadoc, where I can&apos;t find a user guide (do you mean the package summary of lang3 (&lt;a href=&quot;https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/javadocs/api-release/org/apache/commons/lang3/package-summary.html#package_description)?&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/javadocs/api-release/org/apache/commons/lang3/package-summary.html#package_description)?&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Oh, and IMHO the website should be a component in jira.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>

                            <comment id="13934999" author="dmjones500" created="Fri, 14 Mar 2014 13:39:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Yes, the user guide is now contained within the Javadoc summary of the &lt;tt&gt;org.apache.commons.lang3&lt;/tt&gt; package. This change was made during January of this year (see &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-939&quot; title=&quot;Move Documentation from user guide to package-info files&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-939&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-939&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;). <item>
            <title>[LANG-987] DateUtils.getFragmentInDays(Date, Calendar.MONTH) returns wrong days</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-987</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Commons lang3 screwed up my system after upgraded to 3.3 last night!&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;We use DateUtils.getFragmentInDays(Date, Calendar.MONTH) to extract days for later use. Basically (in 3.2), &apos;today&apos; (Mar. 13) returns 13, but, it returns 12 in 3.3!&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I compared the underlying method org.apache.commons.lang3.time.DateUtils.getFragment(Calendar, int, int) between 3.2 and 3.3:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;3.2&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;        &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// Fragments bigger than a day require a breakdown to days
&lt;/span&gt;        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;switch&lt;/span&gt; (fragment) {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;case&lt;/span&gt; Calendar.YEAR:
                result += (calendar.get(Calendar.DAY_OF_YEAR) * MILLIS_PER_DAY) / millisPerUnit;
                &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;break&lt;/span&gt;;
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;case&lt;/span&gt; Calendar.MONTH:
                result += (calendar.get(Calendar.DAY_OF_MONTH) * MILLIS_PER_DAY) / millisPerUnit;
                &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;break&lt;/span&gt;;
        }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;3.3&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;        &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// Fragments bigger than a day require a breakdown to days
&lt;/span&gt;        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;switch&lt;/span&gt; (fragment) {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;case&lt;/span&gt; Calendar.YEAR:
                result += ((calendar.get(Calendar.DAY_OF_YEAR) -1) * MILLIS_PER_DAY) / millisPerUnit;
                &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;break&lt;/span&gt;;
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;case&lt;/span&gt; Calendar.MONTH:
                result += ((calendar.get(Calendar.DAY_OF_MONTH) -1) * MILLIS_PER_DAY) / millisPerUnit;
                &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;break&lt;/span&gt;;
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;default&lt;/span&gt;:
                &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;break&lt;/span&gt;;
        }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Is there ANY ANY reason for adding &apos;-1&apos; in 3.3?! Plus, do you have any unit test for this method?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12701157">LANG-987</key>
            <summary>DateUtils.getFragmentInDays(Date, Calendar.MONTH) returns wrong days</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/blocker.svg">Blocker</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="dmjones500">Duncan Jones</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mustangxu@gmail.com">Jay Xu</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 13 Mar 2014 04:53:05 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 19 Mar 2014 12:24:06 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 13 Mar 2014 21:52:39 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.3</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.3.1</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.time.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13932977" author="dmjones500" created="Thu, 13 Mar 2014 08:06:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is definitely a bug and it was introduced during the fix for &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-951&quot; title=&quot;Fragments are wrong by 1 day when using fragment YEAR or MONTH&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-951&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-951&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;. There are many unit tests covering the method, but for some reason none that use &lt;tt&gt;DateUtils.getFragmentInDays(&amp;lt;foo&amp;gt;, Calendar.MONTH)&lt;/tt&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="13933589" author="mustangxu@gmail.com" created="Thu, 13 Mar 2014 17:32:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Sorry for my tough tone, but this did impact a lot on my system, pls fix this ASAP, thx~&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13933613" author="dmjones500" created="Thu, 13 Mar 2014 17:43:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patches are always welcome &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13934163" author="dmjones500" created="Thu, 13 Mar 2014 21:52:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Found time to take a look at this. Added missing unit tests, so we shouldn&apos;t lose this functionality again.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/r1577332&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/r1577332&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Log:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-987&quot; title=&quot;DateUtils.getFragmentInDays(Date, Calendar.MONTH) returns wrong days&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-987&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-987&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;: DateUtils.getFragmentInDays(Date, Calendar.MONTH) returns wrong days, reported by Jay Xu.&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-984] DurationFormatUtils does not handle large durations correctly</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-984</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;DurationFormatUtils assumes that the the number of days, hours, minutes, seconds and milliseconds can be expressed as an int when converted from a long duration in milliseconds.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However even the number of days can exceed an int if the duration is large enough.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It&apos;s unlikely that such large durations will often be used, but this restriction is not documented. It should be easy enough to use long fields instead of int.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12698351">LANG-984</key>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-983] DurationFormatUtils does not describe format string fully</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-983</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;DurationFormatUtils does not document the format string fully.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It currently only mentions the individual formatting characters.&lt;br/&gt;
It does not mention how repeated characters are handled, nor does it mention quoting.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It does not state whether characters that are not (currently) format &lt;br/&gt;
characters need to be quoted (at present these are assumed to be text).&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12698349">LANG-983</key>
            <summary>DurationFormatUtils does not describe format string fully</summary>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-982] DurationFormatUtils.formatDuration(61999, &quot;s.SSSS&quot;) - ms field size should be 4 digits</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-982</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;DurationFormatUtils.formatDuration(61999, &quot;s.SSSS&quot;)  generates the wrong number of places for the millisecond field. It should produce 61.0999 but it generates 61.999.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is an unlikely format, but there is no indication that the millisecond field is a maximum of 3 digits when it happens to follow a seconds field.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This issue occurs because of the way the code attempts to ensure that 3 places are shown in a format if milliseconds follows seconds.&lt;br/&gt;
The code currently adds 1000 and then drops the first digit.&lt;br/&gt;
The simplest way to allow an arbitrary number of digits is to use at least 3 for the count field.&lt;br/&gt;
Alternatively, if exactly 3 digits are required it would be simpler to just use a count of 3.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12698347">LANG-982</key>
            <summary>DurationFormatUtils.formatDuration(61999, &quot;s.SSSS&quot;) - ms field size should be 4 digits</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-981] DurationFormatUtils#lexx does not detect unmatched quote char</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-981</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The method DurationFormatUtils#lexx does not detect if the format string contains an unmatched single-quote character.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For example &quot;yMd&apos;test&quot; should really be rejected, as the literal string &quot;test&quot; is not properly terminated.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12698245">LANG-981</key>
            <summary>DurationFormatUtils#lexx does not detect unmatched quote char</summary>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-980] DurationFormatUtils uses == for comparing objects</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-980</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;As reported on the ML, Findbugs complains that == is being used to compare objects in the class DurationFormatUtils.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;These objects are the strings which define the various durations: &quot;y&quot;, &quot;M&quot;, &quot;d&quot; etc.  These are final static objects (singletons) so the use of == should be OK but it is not good practice.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;One way to avoid the warnings would be to use an Enum for the singleton objects. For example:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;enum&lt;/span&gt; Duration { YEAR, MONTH, ... }
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; ParseObject y = ParseObject.YEAR;
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; ParseObject M = ParseObject.MONTH;
...
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Note: the package protected fields y, M etc are currently needed for the unit tests.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The above change would then allow the format() method to use a switch statement which would likely be faster than the if chain it has to use now.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Eliminating the warnings for == which are currently safe would make it obvious if == was used elsewhere in an unsafe way.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12698179">LANG-980</key>
            <summary>DurationFormatUtils uses == for comparing objects</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebb">Sebb</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sun, 2 Mar 2014 12:20:23 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 3 Mar 2014 08:00:57 +0000</updated>
                                                            <fixVersion>Patch Needed</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.time.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13917520" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sun, 2 Mar 2014 18:52:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It looks like the only object types ever added as Token values are the 1-char Strings for the duration ids and StringBuilder objects. The Unit test code adds a Number, but the code does not use this feature. Now the StringBuilder objects are only ever used after conversion to a String, so it seems odd to store the StringBuilder rather than the string. I suspect this may be because a 1-char String could be confused with one of the duration ids if it ever got interned.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To avoid repeated use of StringBuffer#toString() whilst still ensuring that duration ids are unique, the Token class could be modified slightly.&lt;br/&gt;
The Object value could be replaced with 2 fields: the type (Duration enum) and a string (if relevant). The Duration enum would need to be extended to include STRING - and renamed as it is no longer just a duration.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This would allow further simplification of the code, e.g. in the equals method. The Token constructors could be adjusted to accept onlly String or enum.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13917678" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Mon, 3 Mar 2014 01:53:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The StringBuilder objects are in fact used by the lexx method to collect the text characters, but that could be done before creating the Token object with the string contents.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There&apos;s another possible simplification - the Tokens are created as a list and then converted to an array - however the code could just use the original list. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also the list of Tokens needs to be searched to determine if it does (or does not) contain various of the duration specifiers.&lt;br/&gt;
The lexx method could build a Set of contained types to avoid scanning the Token list.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-979] TypeUtils.parameterizeWithOwner - wrong format descriptor for &quot;invalid number of type parameters&quot;</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-979</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The TypeUtils.parameterizeWithOwner method uses the following format string:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;invalid number of type parameters specified: expected %s, got %s&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;with parameters that are actually ints.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This means that the parameters are boxed into Integers and then converted to Strings by the formatter.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Seems to me it would make more sense to either create the Strings directly from the ints, or box the ints and use &quot;%d&quot; for the place holders.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12698123">LANG-979</key>
            <summary>TypeUtils.parameterizeWithOwner - wrong format descriptor for &quot;invalid number of type parameters&quot;</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-977] NumericEntityEscaper incorrectly encodes supplementary characters</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-977</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;NumericEntityEscaper will incorrectly encode supplementary unicode characters depending on the char length of the first code point in the string.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To reproduce, run:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; escaped = NumericEntityEscaper.between(0x7f, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Integer&lt;/span&gt;.MAX_VALUE).translate(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;a \uD83D\uDC14 \uD83D\uDCA9&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Expected:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;escaped == &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;a &amp;amp;#128020; &amp;amp;#128169;&quot;&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Actual:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;escaped == &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;a &amp;amp;#128020;&amp;amp;#56340; &amp;amp;#128169;&amp;amp;#56489;&quot;&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The issue lies in CharSequenceTranslator.translate() and the way it checks code points to figure out how many characters it needs to consume.  Specifically, the issue is on &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/blob/trunk/src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/text/translate/CharSequenceTranslator.java#L95&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;line 95&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// contract with translators is that they have to understand codepoints 
&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// and they just took care of a surrogate pair
&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;for&lt;/span&gt; (&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; pt = 0; pt &amp;lt; consumed; pt++) {
    pos += &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Character&lt;/span&gt;.charCount(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Character&lt;/span&gt;.codePointAt(input, pt));
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The point of this code is to check the charCount of the character that was just translated and move ahead by that many characters in the input string.  The bug is that it&apos;s indexing into the string using &apos;pt&apos;, which is &lt;em&gt;always&lt;/em&gt; 0 at the beginning of the loop.  It&apos;s effetively checking the charCount of first character in the string every time.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A patch is attached that fixes the issue and includes supporting unit tests.  Fixing this issue in CharSequenceTranslator uncovered an issue in CsvEscaper/CsvUnescaper caused by the fact that it wasn&apos;t respecting the &quot;code point contract&quot; described in CharSequenceTranslator.translate.  The fix there was to have the translate methods return the string&apos;s code point count rather than character count.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12695277">LANG-977</key>
            <summary>NumericEntityEscaper incorrectly encodes supplementary characters</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
