<item>
            <title>[LANG-796] DateUtils.addDays does not work properly with daylight saving time (DST)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-796</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;DateUtils.addDays&lt;/tt&gt; does not work properly with daylight saving time. The signature of the method is &lt;tt&gt;Date addDays(Date date, int amount)&lt;/tt&gt; and the javadocs says:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;Adds a number of days to a date returning a new object. The original date object is unchanged&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;so if X=date.getTime() is the number of milliseconds of the date in input,&lt;br/&gt;
the expected behaviour is that the returned Date has a number of milliseconds equal to X+amount*(86400000), where 86400000 is the number of milliseconds in one day.&lt;br/&gt;
But when the calculation goes across the DST change date, the number of milliseconds added does not correspond to whole days.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For example, here in Brussels, this code fragment:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;Date input = DateUtils.parseDateStrictly(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;25-03-2012_00:00&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;[] { &lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;dd-MM-yyyy_HH:mm&quot;&lt;/span&gt; });
Date output = DateUtils.addDays(input, 1);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;will give:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&apos;input&apos; equals to &quot;Sun Mar 25 00:00:00 CET 2012&quot;    ==&amp;gt; input.getTime() equals to 1332630000000&lt;br/&gt;
&apos;output&apos; equals to &quot;Mon Mar 26 00:00:00 CEST 2012&quot;  ==&amp;gt; output.getTime() equals to 1332712800000&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;where 1332712800000-1332630000000=82800000 &amp;lt; 86400000&lt;br/&gt;
(in fact 82800000 is equivalent to 23h).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Since &lt;tt&gt;addDays&lt;/tt&gt; is working with objects Date, it should not be influenced by events like the DST.&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Proposed solution: replace the current implementation&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; Date add(Date date, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; calendarField, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; amount) {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (date == &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;) {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throw&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; IllegalArgumentException(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;The date must not be &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
        }
        Calendar c = Calendar.getInstance();
        c.setTime(date);
        c.add(calendarField, amount);
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; c.getTime();
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;based on Calendar with an implementation that works only with Date objects, for example:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; Date add(Date date, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; calendarField, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; amount) {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (date == &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;) {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throw&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; IllegalArgumentException(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;The date must not be &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;null&lt;/span&gt;&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
        }
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; Date(input.getTime() + amount * 86400000l);
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12548305">LANG-796</key>
            <summary>DateUtils.addDays does not work properly with daylight saving time (DST)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="nicola.barbiero">Nicola Barbiero</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 27 Mar 2012 13:20:58 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 22 Oct 2014 14:50:51 +0000</updated>
                                            <version>3.3.2</version>
                                    <fixVersion>Discussion</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.time.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>2</votes>
                                    <watches>5</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13239466" author="adrianc@hlmksw.com" created="Tue, 27 Mar 2012 13:57:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The current behavior is correct. The result added one day. One day is NOT equal to 86400000 milliseconds - as you can see from the result.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13239560" author="nicola.barbiero" created="Tue, 27 Mar 2012 15:34:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;From &lt;a href=&quot;http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/util/Date.html:&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/util/Date.html:&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
&quot;The class Date represents a specific instant in time, with millisecond precision. &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;...&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; the Date class is intended to reflect coordinated universal time (UTC) &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;...&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Nearly all modern operating systems assume that 1 day = 24 &#215; 60 &#215; 60 = 86400 seconds in all cases.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The concept of daylight saving time (DST) is not present in UTC, and UTC is NEVER effected by DST, so a method that receives a Date in input and returns a Date should never be effected by DST.&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time#Daylight_saving&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time#Daylight_saving&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The current behavior would be correct if working on Calendar objects, since a Calendar takes in account the concept of DST.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;By the way, even if the final choice will be to not change the current behavior for this method, at least it should be better documented in its javadoc, to avoid misuses and misunderstanding in its way of working.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13239606" author="adrianc@hlmksw.com" created="Tue, 27 Mar 2012 16:31:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;If you want to perform millisecond arithmetic, then I recommend you use long values and avoid using the DateUtils class.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The JavaDocs seem clear to me - the method adds a day, not 86400000 milliseconds.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13239608" author="tn" created="Tue, 27 Mar 2012 16:36:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I had to deal with DST problems just recently myself:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The behaviour of DateUtils is perfectly valid if you consider your local timezone. The method uses internally the default Calendar instance (that is set to your local timezone) and is thus affected by DST. If you want to operate on UTC dates only, use a Calendar configured for the UTC timezone.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It could be elaborated a bit more in the javadoc, so that people are aware of the fact, but there is nothing wrong with it imho.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13240283" author="nicola.barbiero" created="Wed, 28 Mar 2012 08:11:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;That&apos;s the point: DateUtils.addDays receives in input a Date, that is an absolute time, so it should not be influenced by DST. Using a Calendar configured for the UTC timezone means to not use DateUtils.addDays, since there is no overloading method that receives a Calendar in input.&lt;br/&gt;
As Thomas said, the method uses internally the default Calendar instance, that is set to the local timezone of the server where the code is running, and this is quite problematic in those time of cloud computing, because the code will work differently if the server is located in a zone where DST is applied or not (some countries do not implement any DST at all).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Summarizing, for me the issue is that the user of this method is affected by the TimeZone but he has no way to set this TimeZone, because always the default Calendar instance and the local timezone are used.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13240293" author="tn" created="Wed, 28 Mar 2012 08:36:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The whole idea of DateUtils is to provide convenience methods when manipulating Date objects. The use-case that you describe, and I assume that&apos;s quite a common one, requires a properly configured Calendar object. Now we could add a method like this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;  public static Date add(Date date, int calendarField, int amount, Calendar cal) {
     cal.setTime(date);
     cal.add(calendarField, amount);
     return cal.getTime();
  }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But what&apos;s the point of it? If you already have the Calendar that you want to use, why not just do it straight-away?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The fix that you propose would only support the UTC timezone, and will return wrong results for different timezones in case of a DST. While you are right, when you say that a Date object is not influenced by DST, any manipulation of it is in fact (or better could, depending on the timezone). When you need to operate in UTC time, always use proper configured Calendars (and also Formatters) for the UTC timezone (or set your local timezone to UTC).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13245250" author="tn" created="Tue, 3 Apr 2012 12:13:07 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I was still musing about this issue, and maybe adding an additional version with a TimeZone parameter could make sense:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;public static Date add(Date date, int calendarField, int amount, TimeZone tz) {
     Calendar cal = Calendar.getInstance(tz);
     cal.setTime(date);
     cal.add(calendarField, amount);
     return cal.getTime();
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But to be consistent, this should be done for all methods (e.g. addDays, addMonths, ..), and would definitely bloat the API.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13245300" author="joehni" created="Tue, 3 Apr 2012 13:15:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;What about creating UTCDateUtils instead that operates on UTC and is therefore independent of any TZ? Then we have simply to properly document both types. We could use a package private base class to share common functionality.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13246097" author="tn" created="Wed, 4 Apr 2012 07:53:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I like the idea somehow, but it would also mean to duplicate the signature of a class, as all the methods in DateUtils are static.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Something that I have in mind, is to extract the current interface of DateUtils into a separate class TBD. DateUtils would then provide two static members DEFAULT and UTC, which instantiate the separate class TBD with the corresponding timezones (TimeZone.getDefault() or TimeZone.getTimeZone(&quot;UTC&quot;)). Additionally to mimick the current behavior, the existing static methods in DateUtils would call the corresponding methods of DateUtils.DEFAULT.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Users can instantiate also a TBD instance by providing a custom timezone.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But this is maybe an overkill, the same can be achieved by altering the default Timezone via TimeZone.setDefault. Although there are surely use-cases where this is not possible or desirable (e.g. due to multi-threading).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13461108" author="dmjones500" created="Sat, 22 Sep 2012 10:43:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I agree with Nicola. A class that intends to work with Date values should not be interested in daylight savings. I suspect this was an unintentional error on the part of the original implementation.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;At the very least, the Javadocs need to change to reflect this behaviour.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The issue with changing the code is that people may already be relying on this behaviour. All of the &lt;tt&gt;addXXX&lt;/tt&gt; methods use Calendars and would be impacted.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13461528" author="nicola.barbiero" created="Sun, 23 Sep 2012 22:29:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Right, changing the code now might be dangerous...&lt;br/&gt;
And of course I agree that an update of Javadoc will be harmless for those who are already using the library, and helpful for everyone.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13796579" author="bayard" created="Wed, 16 Oct 2013 08:56:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Javadoc patch needed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14149033" author="dmjones500" created="Fri, 26 Sep 2014 11:23:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve just updated the Javadoc to provide a warning in the opening paragraphs:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Several methods are provided for adding to &lt;tt&gt;Date&lt;/tt&gt; objects, of the form &lt;br/&gt;
&lt;tt&gt;addXXX(Date date, int amount)&lt;/tt&gt;. It is important to note these methods &lt;br/&gt;
use a &lt;tt&gt;Calendar&lt;/tt&gt; internally (with default timezone and locale) and may&lt;br/&gt;
be affected by changes to daylight saving time (DST).&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;We should discuss whether this behaviour should change in a future release. I&apos;ve updated the affected version to the latest, since this is still an issue.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;SVN log:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Author: djones&lt;br/&gt;
Date: Fri Sep 26 11:19:32 2014&lt;br/&gt;
New Revision: 1627753&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;URL: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/r1627753&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://svn.apache.org/r1627753&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Log:&lt;br/&gt;
Added Javadoc warnings related to &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-796&quot; title=&quot;DateUtils.addDays does not work properly with daylight saving time (DST)&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-796&quot;&gt;LANG-796&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Modified:&lt;br/&gt;
    commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/time/DateUtils.java&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14150489" author="adrianc@hlmksw.com" created="Sat, 27 Sep 2014 07:31:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I repeat:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The current behavior is correct. The result added one day. One day is NOT equal to 86400000 milliseconds - as you can see from the result.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14179981" author="jpollak" created="Wed, 22 Oct 2014 14:50:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I am affected by this situation as well, and I agree with &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=nicola.barbiero&quot; class=&quot;user-hover&quot; rel=&quot;nicola.barbiero&quot;&gt;Nicola Barbiero&lt;/a&gt; - As he quoted the Oracle specification at the top of bug: &quot;Nearly all modern operating systems assume that 1 day = 24 &#215; 60 &#215; 60 = 86400 seconds in all cases&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Adding a day should add a 86400 seconds, in all cases, regardless of timezone.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-794] SystemUtils.IS_OS_WINDOWS_2008, VISTA are incorrect</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-794</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;On Windows Server 2008 R2 (a Rackspace Cloud Instance), the values of SystemUtils.IS_OS_WINDOWS_2008 and SystemUtils.IS_OS_WINDOWS_VISTA are incorrect: the former is false and the latter is true.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m not sure how to fix the VISTA flag (as I don&apos;t have an instance to test against), but the cause of WINDOWS_2008 being set to false is that the match explicitly requires the version to be 6.1, where 6.0 can apparently also be the version number for 2008 R2.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Windows Server 2008 R2, Rackspace Cloud Instance&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12546860">LANG-794</key>
            <summary>SystemUtils.IS_OS_WINDOWS_2008, VISTA are incorrect</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="britter">Benedikt Ritter</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="thobbs">Tom Hobbs</reporter>

                            <comment id="13453763" author="bayard" created="Wed, 12 Sep 2012 06:19:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Wondering why we mess with the version. &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.milesdennis.com/2010/05/detecting-which-os-is-running-in-java.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.milesdennis.com/2010/05/detecting-which-os-is-running-in-java.html&lt;/a&gt; seems to imply that osName matches nicely on Windows to the properties we want to set.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14152938" author="dmjones500" created="Tue, 30 Sep 2014 08:18:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Looks like that blog page has moved to: &lt;a href=&quot;http://milesdennis.blogspot.co.uk/2010/05/detecting-which-os-is-running-in-java.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://milesdennis.blogspot.co.uk/2010/05/detecting-which-os-is-running-in-java.html&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14384811" author="hzpz" created="Fri, 27 Mar 2015 22:31:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I agree with &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=bayard&quot; class=&quot;user-hover&quot; rel=&quot;bayard&quot;&gt;Henri Yandell&lt;/a&gt;, on Windows commons-lang should use the value of os.name to determine the version. Take a look at &lt;a href=&quot;http://hg.openjdk.java.net/jdk8u/jdk8u40/jdk/file/tip/src/windows/native/java/lang/java_props_md.c&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://hg.openjdk.java.net/jdk8u/jdk8u40/jdk/file/tip/src/windows/native/java/lang/java_props_md.c&lt;/a&gt; for possible values.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14385247" author="britter" created="Sat, 28 Mar 2015 11:17:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patches welcome!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14385553" author="githubbot" created="Sat, 28 Mar 2015 22:20:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;GitHub user hzpz opened a pull request:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/60&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/60&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-794&quot; title=&quot;SystemUtils.IS_OS_WINDOWS_2008, VISTA are incorrect&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-794&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-794&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;: Use os.name only when determining Windows versions&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    As suggested in previous JIRA comments and according to some other sources (see &lt;a href=&quot;http://lopica.sourceforge.net/os.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://lopica.sourceforge.net/os.html&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a href=&quot;http://hg.openjdk.java.net/jdk7u/jdk7u/jdk/file/tip/src/windows/native/java/lang/java_props_md.c&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://hg.openjdk.java.net/jdk7u/jdk7u/jdk/file/tip/src/windows/native/java/lang/java_props_md.c&lt;/a&gt; for example) the Windows version can be determined by os.name alone. I also added a constant for Windows Server 2012.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    $ git pull &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/hzpz/commons-lang&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/hzpz/commons-lang&lt;/a&gt; &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-794&quot; title=&quot;SystemUtils.IS_OS_WINDOWS_2008, VISTA are incorrect&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-794&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-794&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    &lt;a href=&quot;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/60.patch&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/pull/60.patch&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch&lt;br/&gt;
with (at least) the following in the commit message:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    This closes #60&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-792] ToStringStyle registry may retain entries between invocations - is this a problem?</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-792</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The class ToStringStyle maintains a registry in order to try to detect object cycles (introduced by &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-69&quot; title=&quot;[lang] ToStringBuilder throws StackOverflowError when an Object cycle exists&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-69&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-69&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Multiple instances in the same thread share the same registry (it&apos;s a ThreadLocal - not clear why).&lt;br/&gt;
Entries can be left in the registry on return from calling various methods on the instance.&lt;br/&gt;
Is this a bug? Can object cycles cause problems across method calls?&lt;br/&gt;
If it is intended for the registered objects to remain across method calls, can objects from different instances interfere with each other?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The registry uses a WeakHashMap, so the entries should not cause problems for garbage collection.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;One solution would be to use an instance field to hold the map instead of sharing them.&lt;br/&gt;
Would that use more memory, or be otherwise less efficient?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12545597">LANG-792</key>
            <summary>ToStringStyle registry may retain entries between invocations - is this a problem?</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="8">Not A Problem</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sebb">Sebb</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 8 Mar 2012 02:58:38 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 15 Oct 2013 02:33:00 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 8 Mar 2012 22:28:26 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13225306" author="garydgregory" created="Thu, 8 Mar 2012 17:00:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Howdy,&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A thread local is used so that calling reflectionToString on the same object (and any of its referred objects) from multiple threads works (returns the same String).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If the registry was &lt;em&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; a thread local, then all threads would share the registry and that would lead to some threads not getting a proper toString of an object because another thread already registered it, erroneously thinking it was already visited.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For example for an object o that has one ivar x which itself has a y ivar pointing to &quot;y&quot;:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thread 1: registers x and does a deep toStrings on x&lt;br/&gt;
Thread 2: checks that x is registered, it is, so it uses the default toString for x (not the deep toString)&lt;br/&gt;
Thread 1: ungisters x&lt;br/&gt;
...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thread 1 gets x[y&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot;y&amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;] OK&lt;br/&gt;
Thread 2 gets x&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;y@123&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; BAD&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also, with a thread local, the registry does not need to be a thread-safe data structure.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13225361" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 8 Mar 2012 18:23:58 +0000"  >&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;If the registry was not a thread local, then all threads would share the registry&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;That is only true if the ToStringStyle (TSS) instance is shared between threads.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I had assumed that each ToStringBuilder would use its own TSS instance, but that is not the case.&lt;br/&gt;
Looking again at the code, I see that the ToStringStyle (TSS) classes seem to be intended to be used as singletons which are then shared between threads. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;That explains why the ThreadLocal is needed.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also, I now realise that the earlier problem with the test cases failing on Gump is that some of them created a builder but then failed to use the toString() method on it. That left entries in the registry, and caused the subsequent test to fail if it checked that the registry was empty.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In normal use, the toString() method is required; the registry will then be cleaned up.&lt;br/&gt;
The test cases need to do so too; I&apos;ll fix them up again.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13225610" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 8 Mar 2012 22:28:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Seems to be OK; have added comment to source code to say why ThreadLocal is needed, and updated tests.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-789] SerializationUtils clone method fails to perform some deep cloning</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-789</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;SerializationUtils clone method fails to perform some deep cloning of at least some objects containing Externalizable subobjects.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here is the @version text from the SerializationUtils.java source file:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;SerializationUtils.java 1199718 2011-11-09 12:43:20Z sebb $&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;To reproduce possible bug:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1. Create two classes (let&apos;s call them Parent and Child) and mark both as &quot;implements Externalizable&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2. Write required Externalizable methods readExternal and writeExternal&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;3. Make Child a private member/field of Parent&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;4. Write code to override toString if necessary for Parent and Child&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;5. Create a separate Java class to test creation and cloning of Parent and Child &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;6. In the test class write to code to do this:&lt;br/&gt;
a. Create a Parent object&lt;br/&gt;
b. Create a Child object&lt;br/&gt;
c. Attach Child to Parent via setter&lt;br/&gt;
d. Print out Parent object&lt;br/&gt;
e. Use SerializationUtils.clone() to clone Parent (call it ParentClone)&lt;br/&gt;
f. Print ParentClone&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;7. Compare print output of Parent and ParentClone, observe that ParentClone does not contain Child object&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Windows 7, Java 7 (1.7.0_03), Apache Commons Lang 3.1, NetBeans 7.1&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12544295">LANG-789</key>
            <summary>SerializationUtils clone method fails to perform some deep cloning</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="8">Not A Problem</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="akubot">Harry Levinson</reporter>
                        <labels>
                            <label>,</label>
                            <label>clone,</label>
                            <label>externalizable,</label>
                            <label>serializable</label>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 27 Feb 2012 19:15:00 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 1 Mar 2012 15:40:46 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 1 Mar 2012 15:40:46 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.1</version>
                                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>2</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13219747" author="detinho" created="Thu, 1 Mar 2012 02:37:45 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I tested this on Windows 7 Sun JDK 1.7.0_03 and Ubuntu 10.04 Sun JDK 1.6.0.26, and worked fine. I used this test case:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void testInnerClassImplementsExternalizable() {
        ExternalizableParent parent = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; ExternalizableParent(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;test&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
        ExternalizableParent parentClone = SerializationUtils.clone(parent);
        
        assertEquals(parent.toString(), parentClone.toString());
    }
    
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;private&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;ExternalizableParent &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;implements&lt;/span&gt; Serializable, Externalizable {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;private&lt;/span&gt; ExternalizableChild child;

        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; ExternalizableParent() {}
        
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; ExternalizableParent(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; value) {
            child = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; ExternalizableChild(value);
        }
        
        @Override
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; toString() {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;return&lt;/span&gt; child.value;
        }

        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void readExternal(ObjectInput in) &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; IOException,
                ClassNotFoundException {
            child = (ExternalizableChild)in.readObject();
        }

        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void writeExternal(ObjectOutput out) &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; IOException {
            out.writeObject(child);
        }
    }
    
    &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;private&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;static&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;final&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;ExternalizableChild &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;implements&lt;/span&gt; Serializable, Externalizable {
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; value;

        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; ExternalizableChild() {}
        
        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; ExternalizableChild(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt; value) {
            &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;this&lt;/span&gt;.value = value;
        }

        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void readExternal(ObjectInput in) &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; IOException,
                ClassNotFoundException {
            value = (&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;)in.readObject();
        }

        &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; void writeExternal(ObjectOutput out) &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;throws&lt;/span&gt; IOException {
            out.writeObject(value);
        }
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Are you doing something different?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13220104" author="akubot" created="Thu, 1 Mar 2012 15:40:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks Marcos, closing this issue now.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It turned out to be a bug in my code elsewhere, and not the clone &quot;bug&quot; issue I submitted.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I was able to run a version of your code that ran fine. Also fixed my own code and disabled the clone workaround I developed for the child class, all works fine now.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks again for looking at this, sorry to waste your time!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-788] SerializationUtils throws ClassNotFoundException when cloning primitive classes</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-788</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If a serializable object contains a reference to a primitive class, e.g. int.class or int[].class, the SerializationUtils throw a ClassNotFoundException when trying to clone that object.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;import org.apache.commons.lang3.SerializationUtils;
import org.junit.Test;


public class SerializationUtilsTest {

	
	@Test
	public void primitiveTypeClassSerialization(){
		Class&amp;lt;?&amp;gt; primitiveType = int.class;
		
		Class&amp;lt;?&amp;gt; clone = SerializationUtils.clone(primitiveType);
		assertEquals(primitiveType, clone);
	}
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; 

&lt;p&gt;The problem was already reported as a java bug &lt;a href=&quot;http://bugs.sun.com/view_bug.do?bug_id=4171142&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://bugs.sun.com/view_bug.do?bug_id=4171142&lt;/a&gt; and ObjectInputStream is fixed since java version 1.4.&lt;br/&gt;
The SerializationUtils problem arises because the SerializationUtils internally use the ClassLoaderAwareObjectInputStream that overrides the ObjectInputStream&apos;s&lt;br/&gt;
resoleClass method without delegating to the super method in case of a ClassNotFoundException.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I understand the intention of the ClassLoaderAwareObjectInputStream, but this implementation should also implement a fallback to the original implementation.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For example:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;        protected Class&amp;lt;?&amp;gt; resolveClass(ObjectStreamClass desc) throws IOException, ClassNotFoundException {
            String name = desc.getName();
            try {
                return Class.forName(name, false, classLoader);
            } catch (ClassNotFoundException ex) {
            	try {
            	     return Class.forName(name, false, Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader());
            	} catch (Exception e) {
		     return super.resolveClass(desc);
		}
            }
        }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here is the code in ObjectInputStream that fixed the java bug.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;    protected Class&amp;lt;?&amp;gt; resolveClass(ObjectStreamClass desc)
	throws IOException, ClassNotFoundException
    {
	String name = desc.getName();
	try {
	    return Class.forName(name, false, latestUserDefinedLoader());
	} catch (ClassNotFoundException ex) {
	    Class cl = (Class) primClasses.get(name);
	    if (cl != null) {
		return cl;
	    } else {
		throw ex;
	    }
	}
    }
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12542230">LANG-788</key>
            <summary>SerializationUtils throws ClassNotFoundException when cloning primitive classes</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-786] StringUtils equals() relies on undefined behavior</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-786</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Since the &lt;tt&gt;java.lang.CharSequence&lt;/tt&gt; class was first introduced in 1.4, the JavaDoc block has contained the following note:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;This interface does not refine the general contracts of the equals and hashCode methods. The result of comparing two objects that implement CharSequence is therefore, in general, undefined. Each object may be implemented by a different class, and there is no guarantee that each class will be capable of testing its instances for equality with those of the other.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When the signature of the StringUtils equals() method was changed from &lt;tt&gt;equals(String, String)&lt;/tt&gt; to &lt;tt&gt;equals(CharSequence, CharSequence)&lt;/tt&gt; in R920543, the implementation still relied on calling CharSequence#equals(Object) even though, in general, the result is undefined.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;One example where &lt;tt&gt;equals(Object)&lt;/tt&gt; returns &lt;tt&gt;false&lt;/tt&gt; even though, as CharSequences, two objects represent equal sequences is when one object is an instance of &lt;tt&gt;javax.lang.model.element.Name&lt;/tt&gt; and the other object is a String.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;java version &quot;1.7.0_02&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.7.0_02-b13)&lt;br/&gt;
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 22.0-b10, mixed mode)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Fedora 15 AMD64&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12539203">LANG-786</key>
            <summary>StringUtils equals() relies on undefined behavior</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="dtrebbien">Daniel Trebbien</reporter>
                        <labels>
                            <label>StringUtils</label>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 20 Jan 2012 19:50:47 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 21 Oct 2013 05:46:42 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 23 Jan 2012 17:52:39 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>3.2</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13190049" author="dtrebbien" created="Fri, 20 Jan 2012 19:58:37 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fix&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This re-introduces StringUtils#equals(String, String) and changes StringUtils#equals(CharSequence, CharSequence) to compare chars individually.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13191293" author="mbenson" created="Mon, 23 Jan 2012 17:52:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi, Daniel, and thanks for your contribution!  Notwithstanding the obvious potential for arguments about OO design and method overloading, I have reworked your patch so that &lt;tt&gt;String-String&lt;/tt&gt; comparisons are still handled in the body of the basic &lt;tt&gt;equals(CharSequence, CharSequence)&lt;/tt&gt; method; thus no exception is needed in &lt;tt&gt;StringUtilsTest#testStringUtilsCharSequenceContract()&lt;/tt&gt;.  Specifically I have retained your &lt;tt&gt;StringUtilsEqualsIndexOfTest&lt;/tt&gt; improvements.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;Committed revision 1234915.&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13479161" author="dma_k" created="Thu, 18 Oct 2012 17:25:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think there is still area for improvement: &lt;a href=&quot;http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/main/java/org/apache/commons/lang3/CharSequenceUtils.java?revision=1199894&amp;amp;view=markup#l192&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;line 192 of CharSequenceUtils()&lt;/a&gt; reads&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;TODO: Implement rather than convert to String&lt;/tt&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In my case I have &lt;tt&gt;CharSequence&lt;/tt&gt; that implements a &quot;lazy&quot; string, and &lt;tt&gt;toString()&lt;/tt&gt; implementation is very expensive plus can potentially cause OOM.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thus &lt;tt&gt;CharSequenceUtils.regionMatches()&lt;/tt&gt; should really do char-by-char comparison, leaving the optimization to underlying &lt;tt&gt;CharSequence&lt;/tt&gt; implementation.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13479203" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 18 Oct 2012 18:12:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;@Dmitry: please raise this as a new JIRA issue (you can then link it to this one if you want).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;We have already closed this issue, and your comment is about performance rather than correctness.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-783] Documentation bug: StringUtils.split</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-783</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The documentation for StringUtils.split(String, String, int) contains wrong strings:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;StringUtils.split(&quot;ab de fg&quot;, null, 0)   = &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot;ab&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;cd&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;ef&amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
StringUtils.split(&quot;ab   de fg&quot;, null, 0) = &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot;ab&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;cd&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;ef&amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This should read:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;StringUtils.split(&quot;ab cd ef&quot;, null, 0)   = &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot;ab&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;cd&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;ef&amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
StringUtils.split(&quot;ab   cd ef&quot;, null, 0) = &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot;ab&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;cd&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;ef&amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12535425">LANG-783</key>
            <summary>Documentation bug: StringUtils.split</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/trivial.svg">Trivial</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="sam@rfc1149.net">Samuel Tardieu</reporter>
                        <labels>
                            <label>documentation</label>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 16 Dec 2011 08:38:25 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 28 Dec 2011 05:58:37 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 28 Dec 2011 05:58:37 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.2</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>

                            <timeestimate seconds="300">5m</timeestimate>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-777] jar contains velocity template of release notes</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-777</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The released Java archive of 3.1 contains the velocity template &quot;release-notes.vm&quot; (claiming to be for 3.0.1 anyway) in the Java package &quot;templates&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12532303">LANG-777</key>
            <summary>jar contains velocity template of release notes</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/trivial.svg">Trivial</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="joehni">Joerg Schaible</reporter>
                        <labels>
                            <label>build</label>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 22 Nov 2011 10:23:34 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 15 Oct 2013 02:33:10 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 27 Sep 2012 12:34:13 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.2</fixVersion>
                                    <component>General</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>1</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13155054" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 22 Nov 2011 12:39:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It looks like the RM used a different method for generating the release notes&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Ideally the .vm file is updated, and and then can run&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;mvn changes:announcement-generate&lt;br/&gt;
mv target/announcement/RELEASE-NOTES.txt RELEASE-NOTES.txt&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Commons Parent 22 has a profile for this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;mvn changes:announcement-generate -Prelease-notes&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;but this requires the vm file to be located under&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;src/changes&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;rather than&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;arc/main/resources/templates&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;OK to move the file accordingly?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13155088" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Tue, 22 Nov 2011 13:03:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Alternatively, I suppose one could override the CP release-notes profile to fix the location.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Or copy them to the new location.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Depends on whether there is any need to keep the existing location or not.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13156549" author="bayard" created="Thu, 24 Nov 2011 06:00:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Yeah, I forgot all about the template. It was so simple to write the release notes by hand (changes.xml, then update release notes).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Is there any value in the velocity approach? I know I added it back in August but I&apos;ve no idea why.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13156617" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 24 Nov 2011 09:55:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The file changes.xml is used to create the changes-report.html file, so needs to be kept up to date anyway.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Using the same file for the release notes means that they are consistent.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Note: one can select the required version for the release notes as follows:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;mvn changes:announcement-generate -Dchanges.version=3.1&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This overrides the default, which is taken from the POM version.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13156914" author="bayard" created="Thu, 24 Nov 2011 22:02:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Seems much simpler to edit changes.xml and then copy to the release notes before release. The template approach sounds overly complex.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13156919" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 24 Nov 2011 22:31:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;You don&apos;t often need to edit the template, especially now it does not have a fixed version in it.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Mostly you only need to edit changes.xml and then run&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;mvn changes:announcement-generate -Dchanges.version=x.x&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Check that the new file looks OK, and check it in.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;That&apos;s it.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Try it and see.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13221899" author="tn" created="Sun, 4 Mar 2012 14:19:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The parent pom version 23 defines as default location for the release-notes template:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  src/changes/release-notes.vm&lt;br/&gt;
  src/changes/changes.xml&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So the templates can not slip into the resulting jar. CM3 for example already follows this scheme.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13453767" author="bayard" created="Wed, 12 Sep 2012 06:25:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Noticing we have two release-notes.vm files since r1342642. Not sure what the plan is. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13464665" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 27 Sep 2012 12:34:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Log:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-777&quot; title=&quot;jar contains velocity template of release notes&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-777&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-777&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; jar contains velocity template of release notes&lt;br/&gt;
Merge releases notes into standard location&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Removed:&lt;br/&gt;
    commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/main/resources/templates/release-notes.vm&lt;br/&gt;
Modified:&lt;br/&gt;
    commons/proper/lang/trunk/RELEASE-NOTES.txt&lt;br/&gt;
    commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/changes/changes.xml&lt;br/&gt;
    commons/proper/lang/trunk/src/changes/release-notes.vm&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-776] TypeUtilsTest contains incorrect type assignability assertion due to lost/skipped type variable information during the decision process</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-776</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;TypeUtilsTest&lt;/tt&gt; originally contained the following under #&lt;tt&gt;testIsAssignable()&lt;/tt&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;Assert.assertTrue(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;WRONG!&quot;&lt;/span&gt;, TypeUtils.isAssignable(dingType, disType));
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;For background:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;interface&lt;/span&gt; This&amp;lt;K, V&amp;gt; {
}

&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;Other&amp;lt;T&amp;gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;implements&lt;/span&gt; This&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;, T&amp;gt; {
}

&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;Thing&amp;lt;Q&amp;gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;extends&lt;/span&gt; Other&amp;lt;B&amp;gt; {
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;&amp;lt;B&amp;gt;&lt;/tt&gt; refers to a type parameter on the &lt;tt&gt;TypeUtilsTest&lt;/tt&gt; class itself.&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;tt&gt;disType&lt;/tt&gt; and &lt;tt&gt;dingType&lt;/tt&gt; refer to the generic types of the following fields, respectively:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; This&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;, &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;&amp;gt; dis;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; Thing ding;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thus the assertion in question declares that type &lt;tt&gt;Thing&lt;/tt&gt; is assignable to &lt;tt&gt;This&amp;lt;String, String&amp;gt;&lt;/tt&gt;.  If we start at &lt;tt&gt;This&lt;/tt&gt; we can see that the implementing class &lt;tt&gt;Other&lt;/tt&gt; maps its &lt;tt&gt;T&lt;/tt&gt; type parameter to the &lt;tt&gt;V&lt;/tt&gt; type parameter of &lt;tt&gt;This&lt;/tt&gt;.  From this point we can proceed down to &lt;tt&gt;Thing&lt;/tt&gt; and see that it maps the &lt;tt&gt;B&lt;/tt&gt; type parameter of the enclosing &lt;tt&gt;TypeUtilsTest&lt;/tt&gt; class to the &lt;tt&gt;T&lt;/tt&gt; type parameter of &lt;tt&gt;Other&lt;/tt&gt;.  Thus it is fairly obvious that only a &lt;tt&gt;TypeUtilsTest&amp;lt;String&amp;gt;.Thing&lt;/tt&gt; is assignable to &lt;tt&gt;This&amp;lt;String, String&amp;gt;&lt;/tt&gt;.  From this we can determine that the intent of the message in the original test assertion must indeed have been to flag an incorrect assertion.  This is the associated bug report.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12531869">LANG-776</key>
            <summary>TypeUtilsTest contains incorrect type assignability assertion due to lost/skipped type variable information during the decision process</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="mbenson">Matthew Jason Benson</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mbenson">Matthew Jason Benson</reporter>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-775] TypeUtils.getTypeArguments() misses type arguments for partially-assigned classes</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-775</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;failing test code to add to TypeUtilsTest.testGetTypeArguments():&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;typeVarAssigns = TypeUtils.getTypeArguments(Other.class, This.class);
Assert.assertEquals(2, typeVarAssigns.size());
Assert.assertEquals(&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;.class, typeVarAssigns.get(This.&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class.&lt;/span&gt;getTypeParameters()[0]));
Assert.assertEquals(Other.&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class.&lt;/span&gt;getTypeParameters()[0], typeVarAssigns.get(This.&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class.&lt;/span&gt;getTypeParameters()[1]));
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;These should pass based on:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;interface&lt;/span&gt; This&amp;lt;K, V&amp;gt; {
}

&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;public&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;class &lt;/span&gt;Other&amp;lt;T&amp;gt; &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;implements&lt;/span&gt; This&amp;lt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;String&lt;/span&gt;, T&amp;gt; {
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This case fails because the current code ignores the Other class due to its specifying its own type variables, which is obviously incorrect.  This report is extrapolated from an offline report received by Hen.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12531865">LANG-775</key>
            <summary>TypeUtils.getTypeArguments() misses type arguments for partially-assigned classes</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="mbenson">Matthew Jason Benson</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mbenson">Matthew Jason Benson</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 17 Nov 2011 23:38:26 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 22 Aug 2012 09:25:36 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 18 Nov 2011 00:02:15 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>3.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>3.2</fixVersion>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-772] ClassUtils.PACKAGE_SEPARATOR javadoc contains garbage text</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-772</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;javadoc description of ClassUtils.PACKAGE_SEPARATOR is as follows:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The package separator String: &quot;&amp;amp;#x2e;&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It should be something like the following:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The package separator String: &quot;.&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12531449">LANG-772</key>
            <summary>ClassUtils.PACKAGE_SEPARATOR javadoc contains garbage text</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-771] DateUtils.ceiling does not behave correctly for dates on the boundaries</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-771</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;&lt;tt&gt;DateUtils.ceiling&lt;/tt&gt; does not behave as expected for dates exactly on the boundaries specified.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To be consistent with the name &quot;ceiling&quot;, it follows that if a date is already at its &quot;ceiling&quot;, it should not be pushed any higher.  Yet the current implementation (and, it would appear, all implementations since its creation) of &lt;tt&gt;DateUtils.ceiling&lt;/tt&gt; push a value exactly on its ceiling to the next value.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Observe what happens if the following tests are added to &lt;tt&gt;DateUtilsTest.testCeil()&lt;/tt&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;         &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;double&lt;/span&gt; double4 = 15.0;
         assertEquals(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;ceiling &lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;double&lt;/span&gt;-4 failed&quot;&lt;/span&gt;,
         		double4,
         		&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;Math&lt;/span&gt;.ceil(double4));
         
         Date date4 = dateTimeParser.parse(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;March 30, 2003 01:10:00.000&quot;&lt;/span&gt;);
         assertEquals(&lt;span class=&quot;code-quote&quot;&gt;&quot;ceiling minute-4 failed&quot;&lt;/span&gt;,
         		date4,
         		DateUtils.ceiling(date4, Calendar.MINUTE));
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The first assert passes, as Math.ceil behaves as it should (i.e. Mail.ceil(15.0) = 15.0).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, the second assert fails with:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;   ceiling minute-4 failed expected:&amp;lt;Sun Mar 30 01:10:00 GMT+08:00 2003&amp;gt; but was:&amp;lt;Sun Mar 30 01:11:00 GMT+08:00 2003&amp;gt;
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;as the routine incorrectly (I believe) pushes the value to the next minute.&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Either the method is incorrectly named (&lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-434?focusedCommentId=12855836#comment-12855836&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;as previously suggested&lt;/a&gt;) or it should probably be corrected to be consistent with expected behaviour (using Math.ceil as a benchmark).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If changing the behaviour of &lt;tt&gt;DateUtils.ceiling&lt;/tt&gt; is perceived to have too many flow-on effects (e.g. backwards compatibility issues) then perhaps it should be renamed to &lt;tt&gt;DateUtils.ceil&lt;/tt&gt; to make it consistent with the Math class method name and to make the change in behaviour obvious (and perhaps also have a &lt;tt&gt;DateUtils.floor&lt;/tt&gt; as a synonym for &lt;tt&gt;DateUtils.truncate&lt;/tt&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Windows XP Professional&lt;br/&gt;
Java 1.6&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12531406">LANG-771</key>
            <summary>DateUtils.ceiling does not behave correctly for dates on the boundaries</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="rizariza">Ryan Holmes</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 15 Nov 2011 03:53:05 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sun, 18 Dec 2016 15:41:58 +0000</updated>
                                            <version>3.0.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>Patch Needed</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.time.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>3</votes>
                                    <watches>3</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13480225" author="brady.ellison" created="Fri, 19 Oct 2012 18:33:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Given this behavior the naming of this function is highly misleading.  This ceiling function is not ceiling at all, but a truncate date plus one to the date&apos;s calendar field.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It is probably worth ensuring each item in &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floor_and_ceiling_functions#Relations_among_the_functions&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floor_and_ceiling_functions#Relations_among_the_functions&lt;/a&gt; hold for date math.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The function is exactly equivalent to (plus its variants):&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;Date input = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; Date();
Date truncatedToDate = DateUtils.truncate(input, Calendar.DATE);
Date output = DateUtils.addDays(truncatedToDate, 1);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Naive fix: (only for non-negative dates)&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; field = Calendar.DATE;
Date input = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; Date();
Date truncatedToDate = DateUtils.truncate(input, field);
Date output;
&lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; (input.equals(truncatedToDate)) { &lt;span class=&quot;code-comment&quot;&gt;// Because &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;if&lt;/span&gt; floor(val) == val, then ceil(val) (should)== val.
&lt;/span&gt;  output = truncatedToDate;
} &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;else&lt;/span&gt; {
  output = DateUtils.ceiling(truncatedToDate, field);
}
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13796580" author="bayard" created="Wed, 16 Oct 2013 08:57:27 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Noting as patch needed, though I think overhaul for 4.0 might be a better phrase &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

                    </customfield>

    </item>


<item>
            <title>[LANG-770] StringUtils.join(Object[]) performance issue if .toString() is not trivial</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-770</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I have some code that builds syntax trees, and then uses a combination of TreeNode.toString() and StringUtils.join() to recursively convert that syntax tree to a String representation.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;example .toString() of a SumNode class, where children is a TreeNode[]:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public String toString() {&lt;br/&gt;
    return StringUtils.join(children, &quot;+&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The problem is, StringUtils.join(Object[], String, int, int) is trying to be too smart about preallocating the StringBuffer size it uses internally, as it does:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;bufSize *= ((array&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;startIndex&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; == null ? 16 : array&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;startIndex&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;.toString().length())&lt;br/&gt;
                        + separator.length());&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;followed by implicitly calling .toString() on each object in the array:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;buf.append(array&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;i&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For deep syntax trees, this results in incredibly bad performance, as when traversing the syntax tree, every time we go to the first node, we re-expand the entire tree below that node (which does the same thing with the first node below that, etc).&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12531397">LANG-770</key>
            <summary>StringUtils.join(Object[]) performance issue if .toString() is not trivial</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="8">Not A Problem</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="jbarnett">Joe Barnett</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 15 Nov 2011 01:06:50 +0000</created>
                <updated>Mon, 4 Jun 2012 07:43:23 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 4 Jun 2012 07:43:21 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>3</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="13227221" author="detinho" created="Sun, 11 Mar 2012 20:01:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Seems that the piece of code in the description doesn&apos;t exists anymore. The initial buffer size is being calculated as:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;div class=&quot;code panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;codeContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre class=&quot;code-java&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;code-object&quot;&gt;int&lt;/span&gt; noOfItems = endIndex - startIndex;
....
StringBuilder buf = &lt;span class=&quot;code-keyword&quot;&gt;new&lt;/span&gt; StringBuilder(noOfItems * 16);
&lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Using this implementation solves the issue?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13288392" author="bayard" created="Mon, 4 Jun 2012 07:43:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Agreed. Resolving this as Not A Problem.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-764] StrBuilder has a serialVersionUID but is not serializable - this is inconsistent</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-764</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;StrBuilder has a serialVersionUID but is not serializable.&lt;/p&gt;

If so, then add the interface; if not remove the field.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12530872">LANG-764</key>
            <summary>StrBuilder has a serialVersionUID but is not serializable - this is inconsistent</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
