<item>
            <title>[LANG-676] Potential Autoboxing problems with BooleanUtils methods</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-676</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;FindBugs points out the following are bad:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;org.apache.commons.lang3.BooleanUtils.toBooleanObject(String, String, String, String)&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang3.BooleanUtils.toBooleanObject(String&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang3.BooleanUtils.toBooleanObject(Integer, Integer, Integer, Integer)&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang3.BooleanUtils.toBooleanObject(Integer)&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang3.BooleanUtils.toBooleanObject(int, int, int, int)&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang3.BooleanUtils.negate(Boolean)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For each case it&apos;s because the method returns Boolean, and returns null. That used to be a feature, but apparently that plays merry havoc with autoboxing:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;++NP: Method with Boolean return type returns explicit null (NP_BOOLEAN_RETURN_NULL)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;++A method that returns either Boolean.TRUE, Boolean.FALSE or null is an accident waiting to happen. This method can be invoked as though it returned a value of type boolean, and the compiler will insert automatic unboxing of the Boolean value. If a null value is returned, this will result in a NullPointerException. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The only solution imo is to let autoboxing do its job and remove these methods.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12497425">LANG-676</key>
            <summary>Potential Autoboxing problems with BooleanUtils methods</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bayard">Henri Yandell</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 2 Feb 2011 05:44:09 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sun, 6 Feb 2011 06:58:22 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Thu, 3 Feb 2011 05:17:47 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>3.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12989531" author="pbenedict" created="Wed, 2 Feb 2011 06:38:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think this issue is invalid. There&apos;s nothing wrong with methods that return Boolean objects, which could be null. The method, after all, is toBooleanObject. An object can be null.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12989537" author="bayard" created="Wed, 2 Feb 2011 07:13:04 +0000"  >
&lt;p&gt;So it&apos;s someone&apos;s own fault if they do the following?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  boolean b = BooleanUtils.toBooleanObject(3, 1, 2, 3);&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12989539" author="pbenedict" created="Wed, 2 Feb 2011 07:16:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Absolutely.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12989963" author="bayard" created="Thu, 3 Feb 2011 05:17:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;No other comments, so I&apos;ll close this as wontfix.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12990069" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Thu, 3 Feb 2011 12:02:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Could perhaps add a short note to the Javadoc warning about the possible behaviour under autoboxing?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12991116" author="bayard" created="Sun, 6 Feb 2011 06:58:22 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Adding note on potential NPE if autoboxing occurs per &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-676&quot; title=&quot;Potential Autoboxing problems with BooleanUtils methods&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-676&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-676&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&quot;&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-674] NumberUtils and decimal point character</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-674</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Stevo Slavi&#263; reports on commons-user:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Is there any valid reason why &apos;.&apos; is hardcoded as decimal point&lt;br/&gt;
character in lang.math.NumberUtils, commons-lang (2.6) ? Shouldn&apos;t&lt;br/&gt;
this be locale dependent?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>
        <key id="12497147">LANG-674</key>
            <summary>NumberUtils and decimal point character</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/open.png" description="The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.">Open</status>
                    <statusCategory id="2" key="new" colorName="blue-gray"/>
                                    <resolution id="-1">Unresolved</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bayard">Henri Yandell</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sun, 30 Jan 2011 03:43:15 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sun, 16 Nov 2014 15:39:12 +0000</updated>
                                                            <fixVersion>Patch Needed</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.math.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>1</votes>
                                    <watches>3</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12988557" author="scolebourne" created="Sun, 30 Jan 2011 09:03:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;NumberUtils should match Java source code, which requires a dot.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12988629" author="sslavic" created="Sun, 30 Jan 2011 18:38:27 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;With plain Java I can parse String number representations with either dot or comma as decimal point character depending on locale, but not with commons-lang 2.6 lang.math API. See java.text.NumberFormat, java.text.DecimalFormatSymbols.decimalSeparator.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;E.g.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;NumberFormat.getNumberInstance(Locale.US).parse(sPrice)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;will properly handle price string with dot as decimal point character for US locale while&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;NumberFormat.getNumberInstance(new Locale(&quot;nl&quot;)).parse(sPrice);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;will properly handle price string with comma as decimal point character for Dutch locale.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13096760" author="bentels" created="Sat, 3 Sep 2011 21:09:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I have to say I agree with Stevo that something is rotten in the state of Denmark with this one. True, what exactly is wrong depends on your point of view, but it is definitely something.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If, as Stephen says, the semantics of NumberUtils should match those of Java sourcecode, then the simple problem is that the documentation on the methods in NumberUtils doesn&apos;t SAY that. Or otherwise doesn&apos;t say that you&apos;re supposed to use input formatted according to the en_US locale.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;From a different point of view, the (larger) problem may indeed be that the NumberUtils methods do not take locale into account. In the nl locale, as Stevo says, the value &quot;123,4&quot; is a valid number equivalent to 1234/10.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Perhaps a good solution is to do both: overload all the methods that take String arguments to take a Locale argument as well, then put in the documentation that the existing methods implicitly use locale en_US.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="13797711" author="bayard" created="Thu, 17 Oct 2013 08:23:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Provided it doesn&apos;t balloon the source + API, I like Ben&apos;s solution. Improve documentation and provide the Locale option.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14189911" author="mtruchado" created="Thu, 30 Oct 2014 10:29:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hi&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I was hit yesterday by this issue. As today the docummentation is:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;#8211;&lt;br/&gt;
public static boolean isNumber(String str)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Checks whether the String a valid Java number.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Valid numbers include hexadecimal marked with the 0x qualifier, scientific notation and numbers marked with a type qualifier (e.g. 123L).&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;#8211;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It might be useful to add a hint warning about the use of locales and this class do not play well together. A NumberUtils that supports locale would be an excellent feature, play with parsing/unparsing requires ugly code taking care of checked exceptions and so on.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="14213947" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Sun, 16 Nov 2014 15:39:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;One might say that isNumber uses the &apos;Java&apos; Locale.&lt;br/&gt;
AFAIK Java does not allow anything other than &quot;.&quot; as the decimal point marker.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, I agree that other methods in the class might benefit from Locale-specific versions.&lt;br/&gt;
And the ones that assume a specific Locale should say so.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>

            <title>[LANG-672] Doc bug in DateUtils#ceiling</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-672</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformatted panel&quot; style=&quot;border-width: 1px;&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;preformattedContent panelContent&quot;&gt;
&lt;pre&gt;For example, if you had the datetime of 28 Mar 2002
     * 13:45:01.231, if you passed with HOUR, it would return 28 Mar
     * 2002 13:00:00.000.  If this was passed with MONTH, it would
     * return 1 Mar 2002 0:00:00.000. &lt;/pre&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Looks like copy-paste from truncate. (the dates are incorrect)&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment></environment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-666] StringUtils.stripEnd() using a &apos;.&apos; as an &quot;any&quot; character</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-666</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The documentation for stripEnd() indicates that the second parameter should be the string to stip from the end of the first paramater. This mostly works, but I think I found a case where it doesn&apos;t and that&apos;s when there is a period &apos;.&apos; character in the stripChars. It seems to be counting the period as a regex anychar. Example code :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		// trying to strip the cents from a dollar amount&lt;br/&gt;
		String result = StringUtils.stripEnd(&quot;120.00&quot;, &quot;.00&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
		System.out.println(&quot;Expected \&quot;120\&quot;, got \&quot;&quot; + result + &quot;\&quot;&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;		// maybe we should escape the dot?&lt;br/&gt;
		result = StringUtils.stripEnd(&quot;120.00&quot;, &quot;&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;.00&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
		System.out.println(&quot;Expected \&quot;120\&quot;, got \&quot;&quot; + result + &quot;\&quot;&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;JAVA 6, mac os X&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12492755">LANG-666</key>
            <summary>StringUtils.stripEnd() using a &apos;.&apos; as an &quot;any&quot; character</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="6">Invalid</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="neodem">Vincent Fumo</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 8 Dec 2010 18:01:14 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 1 Jan 2011 06:47:53 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 8 Dec 2010 20:01:09 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.5</version>
                                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12969401" author="neodem" created="Wed, 8 Dec 2010 18:02:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;sample code&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12969457" author="sebb@apache.org" created="Wed, 8 Dec 2010 20:01:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The second parameter is not a String - it is the &lt;b&gt;set&lt;/b&gt; of characters to strip.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So StringUtils.stripEnd(&quot;120.00&quot;, &quot;.00&quot;) - which is the same as StringUtils.stripEnd(&quot;120.00&quot;, &quot;.0&quot;) - results in &quot;12&quot; because there is a &quot;0&quot; on the end.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, StringUtils.stripEnd(&quot;121.00&quot;, &quot;.0&quot;) gives &quot;121&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                            <attachment id="12465819" name="StringUtilsTest.java" size="1158" author="neodem" created="Wed, 8 Dec 2010 18:02:46 +0000"/>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                                            <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">

                            <customfieldvalue>Wed, 8 Dec 2010 20:01:09 +0000</customfieldvalue>

                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12314020" key="com.atlassian.jira.plugins.jira-development-integration-plugin:devsummary">
                        <customfieldname>Development</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                        <customfield id="customfield_12313422" key="com.atlassian.jirafisheyeplugin:jobcheckbox">
